column1: WASHINGTON --  Bryce Harper sat out after a procedure to fix an ingrown toenail. Jayson Werth has been sidelined for a week with a bad hamstring and the plan is to put him on the disabled list.	So what if two of Washington's best hitters watched from the dugout Friday night? With extra-base hits coming from lower in the order
column2: the Nationals extended their season-high winning streak to five games.	Ian Desmond's three hits included a two-run homer and an RBI double
column3: and Danny Espinosa and Kurt Suzuki each drove in a pair of runs with a double
column4: helping Washington beat the Chicago Cubs 7-3 for its seventh victory in the past eight games.	"When your 3-hole hitter's out of there
column5: Washington manager Davey Johnson said, referring to Harper, and you score a bunch of runs
column6: that's big."	Desmond was reminded of the manner in which the Nationals compiled a majors-best 98 wins in 2012 despite a series of injuries to everyday players.	"Last year
column7: we were missing guys throughout the whole season
column9: said Desmond, who singled and scored in the second, homered in the fourth and doubled in the fifth. We just found a way."	Ross Detwiler (2-3) gave up two runs in 6 2/3 innings
column10: and Craig Stammen got the last seven outs.	"He wasn't real happy when I hooked him
column11: Johnson said about Detwiler. That's good. I like that."	Chicago's Jeff Samardzija (1-5) lost his fifth decision in a row by allowing seven runs -- five earned -- and eight hits. He threw 73 pitches in his five innings
column12: matching his shortest outing of the season.	Samardzija said he was not bothered by a cut on his right index finger from a start April 24.	"Felt good. Felt about as best as I could all year
column13: the right-hander said. That's the frustrating part of it
column14: when you've got your pitches and you feel good and you get that outcome."	Making his first start in the leadoff slot this season
column15: Chicago's Starlin Castro delivered doubles in each of his first two at-bats
column16: including to begin the game. He made it 1-0 in the first on Anthony Rizzo's groundout.	Suzuki's two-run double off the wall in right-center put Washington ahead 2-1 in the second.	"I never complain about getting hits. My defense is my priority
column17: but it definitely feels good
column18: said Suzuki, a catcher. Being in the bottom of the lineup
column19: when guys are out there
column20: you just want to drive them in."	One of the runners who scored reached on an infield single
column21: while the other got aboard when Samardzija failed in two attempts to start a double play by fielding the ball with his pitching hand and was charged with an error -- making both runs unearned.	"That was kind of the big mess
column22: Cubs manager Dale Sveum said. We've got to field a ground ball back to us. We seem to make a mistake
column23: and we can't make a pitch after that."	Chicago tied it in the third when Samardzija and Castro hit consecutive doubles. Castro later was thrown out at home when trying to score on Rizzo's single. Right fielder Roger Bernadina
column24: starting because Harper and Werth were out
column25: got his second assist of the season with his throw
column26: and Suzuki dived to tag Castro.	Desmond put Washington back out front with his fifth homer
column27: driving an 0-1 pitch barely over the wall in left to make it 4-2. Soon as the bat made contact with the ball
column28: Samardzija spun around and yelled.	Things didn't get much better in the fifth
column29: when the Nationals tacked on three more runs on consecutive doubles by Desmond and Espinosa.	"They're due
column30: Johnson said, to start doing their thing."	Game notes	 Samardzija's lone win came on Opening Day against Pittsburgh. ... Nationals GM Mike Rizzo said Werth has a "very slight strain" of his hamstring and the move to the DL would be backdated to May 2. Rizzo expects Werth to be able to return the first day he's eligible
column31: May 18. Johnson indicated Eury Perez will be called up from Triple-A Syracuse. ... Harper tweeted a photo of his bloody right big toe. Rizzo and Johnson both said they expect Harper to be available Saturday. ... The Cubs activated RHP Kyuji Fujikawa from the DL and optioned RHP Rafael Dolis to Triple-A Iowa. Fujikawa
column32: out since April 13 with a straight right forearm
column33: pitched a scoreless seventh inning Friday. ... On Saturday
column35: 3.45 ERA) will face Cubs RHP Edwin Jackson (0-5
column36: 6.39). Jackson was with Washington last season
column37: then signed a $52 million
column38: four-year deal with the Cubs as a free agent. "Been a slow start to say the least. Not exactly how I had it envisioned

Jackson said.	Randy Arozarena celebrates with his family at home after learning he won the 2021 AL Rookie of the Year. DETROIT -- Before the game Friday, Jim Leyland called Miguel Cabrera and Prince Fielder the best 3-4 combination in the lineup he's ever had.	The veteran manager's timing was perfect.	Cabrera and Fielder each hit a long home run later that night, and the Detroit Tigers beat the Cleveland Indians 10-4. Fielder's third-inning solo shot landed near the No. 42 honoring Jackie Robinson on the brick facade beyond the wall in right-center field. Cabrera's three-run homer the following inning came down below Hank Greenberg's retired No. 5 in left-center at Comerica Park.	I just kind of let 'em play
column40: stay out of their way. ... I think that's what you're supposed to do
column41: Leyland said. We're very fortunate
column42: obviously
column43: to have both of them."	Detroit's Max Scherzer (5-0) allowed four runs and five hits in eight innings. He struck out seven without a walk.	Corey Kluber (2-2) allowed eight runs and 11 hits in 4 2/3 innings.	Andy Dirks also homered for the Tigers
column44: and Omar Infante had three hits
column45: including two doubles. Jhonny Peralta doubled twice as well.	The Tigers trailed 1-0 before Alex Avila's two-run double in the second. Torii Hunter drove home Avila with a single to right
column46: although he was tagged out near first base on the throw back to the infield for the last out of the inning -- preventing another run from scoring on the play.	Fielder's homer went an estimated 460 feet -- according to a Tigers' spokesman
column47: who cited ESPN Stats & Info.	"That was unbelievable
column48: Cabrera said. Every time he goes to the plate
column49: it's like we expect he's going to hit the ball so far
column50: because we know what kind of power he has."	The Indians answered with a run in the fourth when Nick Swisher tripled and scored on Carlos Santana's groundout.	Detroit broke the game open in the bottom half. With one out
column51: Infante hit his second double of the game and took third on Austin Jackson's single. After Hunter struck out
column52: Cabrera hit his seventh homer of the year. The defending Triple Crown winner has 40 RBIs in 33 games in 2013.	"When you get RBIs
column53: that means people are on base
column54: obviously
column55: Leyland said. We've done a good job of that for him
column56: and he's taken advantage of that."	Avila had three RBIs on Friday -- his fifth-inning single scored Peralta to make it 8-2.	"I made too many mistakes with the cutter
column57: Kluber said. I left one over the plate to Cabrera
column58: and they got a couple more hits off that exact same pitch."	Scherzer's previous start was Detroit's 17-2 victory over Houston last weekend. He received plenty of support this time
column60: and he retired eight in a row after Swisher's triple.	"That's one of the best pitchers in the game
column61: and we got four runs off him
column63: Indians manager Terry Francona said. He just pounds the strike zone and then he's got the wipe-out changeup
column64: so you aren't going to get much off him without scratching and clawing. I wish we had gotten 10 off him
column65: but that's not too likely."	Cleveland
column66: which entered the day with a major league-leading 49 homers
column67: didn't hit any Friday. The Indians did scratch out a couple runs in the seventh on an RBI groundout by Mark Reynolds and a sacrifice fly by Michael Brantley.	Dirks hit a solo homer down the line in right in the bottom of the seventh to make it 9-4
column68: and Victor Martinez hit a run-scoring single in the eighth.	Scherzer threw 103 pitches. He has never thrown a complete game. ... The Tigers have won 29 of their last 37 games against Cleveland at Comerica. ... Avila was only able to advance from second to third on Infante's bloop double in the second -- second baseman Jason Kipnis almost caught the ball
column69: so Avila had to stay near second. ... Detroit ace Justin Verlander (4-2) faces Cleveland's Ubaldo Jimenez (2-2) on Saturday night.	Detroit got a jump-start on the winter signings

column1: BOSTON --  Jon Lester was inducing Toronto's aggressive batters to make outs by getting them to swing at first pitches -- until Macier Izturis came up in the sixth.	First pitch. Two-out double to left field. End of bid for perfect game and no-hitter.	But Izturis was the only Blue Jay to reach base as the Boston Red Sox broke a three-game losing streak with a 5-0 win on Friday night.	"The no-hitter
column4: the stars got to be perfectly aligned for you
column5: Lester said.	He should know.	Lester (5-0) threw a no-hitter on May 19, 2008, beating the Kansas City Royals 7-0. Just nine days shy of the fifth anniversary of that gem, the left-hander retired the first 17 batters before Izturis lined a clean double several feet over the outstretched arm of third baseman Will Middlebrooks that landed just inside the foul line. Lester then ended the inning by striking out pinch-hitter Adam Lind.	If that ball's two feet to (the) left
column8: what we wanted to throw especially to an aggressive hitter. He did a good job of hitting it."	Catcher Jarrod Saltalamacchia could have a tough time forgetting it.	"As soon as the game was over I started thinking about it
column10: first pitch. I'm going to have nightmares about it to be honest with you."	The closest the Blue Jays came to another hit was Brett Lawrie's low liner starting the sixth that center fielder Jacoby Ellsbury caught easily.	"He was throwing everything
column11: Toronto's J.P. Arencibia said. I think he used our aggressiveness against us a little bit. He's pretty special when you could throw cutter
column16: and on both sides of the plate. The guy's one of the best in the game for a reason. He showed that tonight."	Lester wasn't the only pitcher to give up only one hit Friday. St. Louis' Shelby Miller gave up a leadoff single then retired 27 in a row in a 3-0 victory over Colorado.	Lester finished with five strikeouts in the 10th complete game and third shutout of his career
column17: effectively mixing his pitches and locating them precisely. He threw just 118 pitches -- only 58 in the first five innings -- and retired the first batter in each of the first three innings on one pitch apiece.	"We've always seen him good. He's one of the better ones in the game
column18: Toronto manager John Gibbons said. He carved us up pretty good tonight."	But the Red Sox led only 1-0 before scoring four runs in the seventh.	"In the seventh we were able to bunch some hits together
column19: which was kind of elusive
column20: Boston manager John Farrell said.	Boston continued to waste numerous opportunities. It left runners on base in each of the first seven innings after stranding runners in all nine innings of Thursday night's 5-3 win over the Minnesota Twins.	They scored in the second against Ramon Ortiz (0-1) when Daniel Nava walked, took third on a single by Saltalamacchia and scored when shortstop Izturis fielded Middlebrooks' grounder but his throw to start a potential inning-ending double play eluded second baseman Mark DeRosa.	The Red Sox finally built a comfortable lead in the seventh.	Singles by Ellsbury and Shane Victorino put runners at first and second and they moved up on a wild pitch by Brett Cecil. Dustin Pedroia singled in a run, but the next two batters struck out. Then Saltalamacchia doubled in two runs and Middlebrooks drove in another with his second double of the game.	Friday's outing was the fourth time Lester allowed just one hit while pitching at least seven innings -- and the third time against Toronto.	The other two were over eight innings in a 1-0 win in Boston on April 29, 2008, and seven innings in a 2-0 win at Toronto on April 28, 2010. He also did it against Kansas City in eight innings of a 1-0 win on July 18, 2006.	Then there was the no-hitter in his first full season when he relied on veteran catcher Jason Varitek to tell him what to throw.	I feel like back then (I was) such a thrower
column21: not really a pitcher. I think the best way to put it is
column24: obviously going through this a couple of times and (I'm) a little bit more mature and understanding what I'm trying to do."	And that made his catcher's job simpler.	"My job was easy. I put the glove there and he hit it
column25: Saltalamacchia said. I don't think whoever we were facing could have hit him."	Game notes	 The last Red Sox pitcher to allow one runner in a complete game was Josh Beckett in a one-hitter at Tampa Bay on June 15
column26: 2011. ... Toronto designated hitter Rajai Davis left the game with a left oblique strain. Lind pinch hit for him in the sixth. ... Clay Buchholz (6-0) pitches for Boston against Mark Buehrle (1-2) in the second game of the three-game series Saturday. ... Toronto's six-game winning streak at Fenway ended. column1: CINCINNATI --  Brandon Phillips homered and made a spectacular rally-busting play -- using his left knee to get a forceout and start a double play -- as the Cincinnati Reds beat the Milwaukee Brewers 4-3 on Friday night.	Phillips had an RBI single off Yovani Gallardo (3-2) and added a solo homer in the seventh after making a saving play in the top of the inning. With two Brewers aboard
column2: he got to Ryan Braun's grounder up the middle
column3: tagged second base with his left knee while falling down and threw to first for a double play.	The Reds won for the fifth time in seven games. Cincinnati is 14-6 at Great American Ball Park
column4: the most home wins in the majors.	Milwaukee got solo homers from Jean Segura and Braun
column5: but lost for the seventh time in eight games.	Alfredo Simon (3-1) threw two innings in relief of rookie left-hander Tony Cingrani. Aroldis Chapman gave up a run on a wild pitch in the ninth while getting his eighth save in as many chances.	Carlos Gomez went 0-for-4 and grounded into a double play
column6: ending his hitting streak at a career-best 14 games.	Neither Gallardo nor Cingrani lasted more than four innings on a wet night
column7: testing both bullpens' depth. Both were stingy
column8: but Cincinnati's had a one-run lead to hold. Reds relievers allowed three hits and four walks in five innings.	The Brewers gave up eight hits and nine walks.	The Reds pulled ahead 2-0 in the third on Phillips' two-out RBI single and Jay Bruce's double off the glove of Norichika Aoki in right field. Bruce improved to .419 against Gallardo.	Zack Cozart's RBI single in the fourth put the Reds up 3-2. Gallardo gave up five hits and five walks in his four innings
column9: throwing 100 pitches.	Cingrani has relied on his fastball to retire batters
column10: getting a lot of strikeouts while piling up high pitch counts. He's also given up a lot of homers -- six in five starts
column11: tied with Bronson Arroyo for the team lead.	Segura led off the fourth with a homer that barely eluded the top of Bruce's glove in right field and bounced off the top of the wall before continuing into the stands. Braun homered to right field on the next pitch
column12: giving him eight overall and a season-high 11-game hitting streak.	Cingrani lasted only four innings
column13: giving up five hits and two walks while throwing 85 pitches. It was the third time in the Reds' past four games that their starter lasted five innings or less.	The Reds activated catcher Ryan Hanigan off the disabled list before the series opener. Hanigan
column15: had been sidelined since April 21 by a strained left oblique. Hanigan had a pair of singles and made a diving catch behind the plate on Segura's sacrifice bunt attempt.	Game notes	 Steady rain fell through the early innings. .... The Reds designated C Corky Miller for assignment
column16: opening a roster spot. ... OF Chris Heisey is expected to start a rehab assignment soon. He's been sidelined since April 29 by a pulled right hamstring. ... Cingrani picked Aoki off first base in the third inning. Aoki reached in all five plate appearances. ... RH Hiram Burgos (1-0) starts Saturday against the Reds

column1: NEW YORK --  The umpires got this one right.	Garrett Jones hit a three-run homer -- a call that was correctly overturned by baseball's beleaguered umps -- and Wandy Rodriguez pitched the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 7-3 victory over the New York Mets on Friday night.	With runners at the corners in the fifth inning
column2: Jones hit a drive to right off Shaun Marcum (0-3) that just cleared a leaping Marlon Byrd. The ball caromed back onto the field off the bottom of a black retaining wall just above the fence and initially was ruled in play.	Jones ended up on third and Pirates manager Clint Hurdle came out for a quick chat with crew chief Joe West
column3: who cracked a smile as the discussion began. The umpires went inside to look at the replay and
column5: came back on the field and signaled home run.	"It was barely over the top of the fence and careened back
column6: West said. So everything worked like it's supposed to."	It's been a rough week for umpires
column7: who botched a home run review Wednesday in Cleveland and goofed on a pitching-change rule the next night in Houston. Major League Baseball executive vice president Joe Torre said Angel Hernandez's crew made an "improper call" in Cleveland
column8: and MLB suspended umpire Fieldin Culbreth for two games Friday because he was in charge in Houston.	Culbreth and the rest of his crew -- Brian O'Nora
column9: Bill Welke and Adrian Johnson -- were also fined an undisclosed amount.	Hurdle wouldn't reveal what it was that made West grin: "That's between me and the Cowboy
column10: he said with a smile of his own.	West explained that he simply inquired if the manager was asking nicely" for a review.	"And he says
column12: 'Sure.' "	"I had Clint when he first started as a player
column13: West said. It was very professional
column14: the way it should be."	Jones doubled twice and leadoff man Starling Marte also had three hits for the Pirates
column15: who improved to 4-13 at Citi Field. Pittsburgh had lost four of five overall
column16: including the opener of this four-game series Thursday.	Handed an early lead
column17: Rodriguez (3-2) allowed six hits over six innings to win for the first time in four starts. He gave up Anthony Recker's first homer for the Mets but worked around a leadoff double in the fourth and held New York to 0 for 9 with runners in scoring position.	"He was able to get through innings and leave runners on base
column18: Hurdle said. He gave us what we needed."	Mets captain David Wright went down after fouling a pitch off the inside of his left knee in the first inning
column19: but stayed in the game until he was lifted in the ninth.	"It was pretty sore
column20: but he said he thought he could play
column21: manager Terry Collins said.	Rodriguez improved to 4-0 in his last five starts against New York and 6-2 overall. Vin Mazzaro tossed two scoreless innings and Jason Grilli retired Ruben Tejada with two on, making him perfect in 14 save chances this season.	We needed to win the game
column22: Hurdle said, explaining why he went to Grilli.	Pirates reliever Jose Contreras gave up a solo homer to Jordany Valdespin and an RBI single to Andrew Brown in the ninth.	Marcum looked uncomfortable on the mound and worked deliberately all night. He has failed to get through the fifth inning in any of his three starts for the Mets since beginning the season on the disabled list.	I feel good. The thing is
column24: Marcum said. When you don't throw 95 (mph) and the ball's up in the zone
column25: they're going to get hit. The main thing is I've got to get back to locating and getting the ball down in the zone."	The right-hander had three 1-2-3 innings but still gave up six runs and nine hits. He also hit two batters with pitches.	Jones opened a three-run second with a double to left-center
column26: the first of four straight hits off Marcum. Pedro Alvarez had an RBI single and Rodriguez drove in a run with a bases-loaded smash up the middle that knocked Marcum's glove off his left hand.	The play turned into a 1-4-6 forceout after the ball deflected to second baseman Justin Turner. Marcum was checked twice by a trainer but remained in the game.	"I'm very
column27: very worried about his hand. I thought for sure he broke his thumb the way the ball came off it
column28: Collins said. But the X-rays were negative
column29: so we'll just get him on the side and
column30: hopefully
column31: he continues to get a little bit better."	Marcum said his hand was "still a little sore
column32: but it should be good to go."	Pittsburgh made it 3-0 when Tejada struggled to get the ball out of his glove and double-clutched a throw on Marte's run-scoring single to shortstop. The Pirates
column33: who batted around in the inning
column34: could easily have scored more if Jose Tabata hadn't been cut down at third for the first out on Alvarez's single to right.	The homer by Jones extended Pittsburgh's lead to 6-0. Even he wasn't sure if his drive cleared the wall.	"It looked like it hit the top of the fence a little bit and kind of ricocheted off the fence. I couldn't really tell so I just kept running
column35: Jones said. It always feels good when they're able to come on the field and twirl a finger."	The clutch hitting was a welcome change for the Pirates
column36: who went 0 for 7 with runners in scoring position Thursday night. They entered 4 for 45 (.089) in those situations over the previous six games.	Pittsburgh has homered in 11 of its last 12 games.	Game notes	 It was the fourth home run review of the season for the Pirates. ... Pittsburgh C Russell Martin sat out and said his neck stiffened up again after he returned action Thursday. He hopes to be back in the lineup Sunday. ... LHP Francisco Liriano is set to come off the disabled list and make his Pirates debut Saturday against Mets LHP Jonathon Niese (2-3
column37: 4.66 ERA). Liriano has been sidelined all season while recovering from a broken right arm. Niese's back was feeling much better than a week ago

column2: Fla. --  Alex Cobb wasn't sure if he should be elated or disappointed.	The Tampa Bay pitcher struck out 13 in fewer than five innings against the San Diego Padres on Friday night. The Rays won 6-3; however
column3: Cobb didn't feel as though he'd truly done his job.	"I don't know if that's a good thing
column4: Cobb said when told he'd become the first player in major league history to fan that many batters and fail to make it through the fifth. As a starting pitcher
column5: you want to go at least five innings every time out."	The right-hander left after throwing 117 pitches. He recorded 12-of-14 outs on strikeouts -- four of them in the third
column6: when a wild pitch on strike three allowed Will Venable to reach base.	The other outs were recorded on grounders to shortstop in the first and third base in the fourth.	"I can't really explain why or how that happened. It was just one of those weird days
column8: that's not my goal. I never go into a game trying to strike everybody out. I was trying to put balls over the plate and have them make weak contact
column9: and they were swinging and missing."	The Padres struck out 18 times.	"He had his changeup going and it was tough to differentiate that from the fastball
column10: and he had us on our heels the whole night
column11: Venable said. He pitched really well
column12: and we just weren't able to make the adjustment."	Roberts and Zobrist both delivered two-run singles in the seventh
column13: when reliever Dale Thayer (0-2) inherited a 3-2 lead from Padres starter Edinson Volquez. Jake McGee (1-2) pitched one inning for the victory
column14: and Fernando Rodney worked a scoreless ninth for his fifth save.	Venable and Carlos Quentin hit solo homers off Cobb in the first for San Diego. Chris Denorfia also singled twice off the Tampa Bay starter
column16: five hits
column17: one walk and hit a batter.	Trailing 3-2
column18: Cobb struck out Chase Headley and Quentin to begin the fifth. He was removed after walking Yonder Alonso
column19: ending a streak of Tampa Bay starting pitchers working at least five innings in every game this season at 34 -- the second-longest stretch to begin a season behind the 1981 Pittsburgh Pirates (45).	Rays manager Joe Maddon had no regrets about not allowing Cobb to continue.	"I just could not permit it and feel good about myself at that point. His career is way too important to him and his family and to us
column20: Maddon said.	At the end of the day it's about the Rays. And for me
column21: it's about the future of these players. ... To have him injure himself because he's going to throw 125 pitches in five innings
column22: that would be on me. You have to be careful at that point."	Umpires Fieldin Culbreth
column24: Bill Welke and Adrian Johnson worked the game. Earlier in the day
column25: Major League Baseball suspended Culbreth for two games because he was in charge of the crew when it allowed Astros manager Bo Porter to improperly switch relievers in the middle of an inning on Thursday.	Culbreth
column26: O'Nora
column27: Welke and Johnson were also fined an undisclosed amount after MLB admitted its umpires made a mistake for the second straight day.	Culbreth told a pool reporter after Friday's game that he takes "all the responsibility" for what happened.	As for the discipline?	"I look at it that baseball has high standards for their umpires and I have high standards for myself and I didn't meet those standards last night
column28: so I am absolutely OK with everything
column29: Culbreth said.	Cobb had nine strikeouts in the first three innings. He worked an extended third, when his wild pitch enabled Venable to reach base. The Padres center fielder stole second and third base, then scored on a balk to make it 3-0.	The Rays starter became the second Tampa Bay pitcher to fan four batters in an inning, joining Jeremy Hellickson, who did it against Detroit on Aug. 25, 2011.	Volquez allowed three runs and three hits in six innings. Evan Longoria had two of the hits off the right-hander, including a RBI single in the third. column7: Johnson said. It's not really anything I'm real focused on. It's great

column1: ST. LOUIS -- Shelby Miller gave up a single to start the game then nothing else. Not a walk or a hit batter. No one even reached on an error.	Nothing.	The St. Louis Cardinals rookie was perfect after that leadoff single by Eric Young Jr.
column2: retiring 27 in a row for his first career complete game
column3: 3-0 over the Colorado Rockies on Friday night.	"I feel really good
column4: Miller said. It's definitely the best game I've thrown in my life. How it finished was unbelievable. It was a great experience. Yadi (catcher Yadier Molina) was calling a great game and they were making great plays for me. It was a start I'll remember the rest of my life."	Miller (5-2) struck out Young to end it with his 13th K
column5: tying a Cardinals rookie record.	Young felt fortunate just to reach base at all.	"It was a jam shot and I just put it in a good location
column6: Young said. I was just fortunate enough to find grass.	"He was working both sides of the plate
column7: using his fastball. He had great command
column8: Young added. His battery mate back there is obviously one of the best game. It was a good combo for them."	Miller agreed with Young's assessment of Molina.	"I say it time and time again
column11: Miller said. He was calling the right thing all night. He's done a terrific job all year and he's helping me out tremendously. I'm happy he's my catcher
column12: that's for sure."	The one-hitter was the fewest hits allowed by a Cardinals pitcher since Bud Smith tossed a no-hitter on Sept. 3
column14: and it was the second one-hitter of the night in the major leagues. Boston's Jon Lester was perfect until he allowed a two-out double in the sixth against Toronto.	In a near-perfect performance
column16: St. Louis manager Mike Matheny said. How he held his composure
column17: made real good pitches all night long against a very good offense."	Miller lowered his ERA to 1.39
column18: which is the lowest for a Cardinals pitcher in his first eight starts since Howie Pollet had a 2.09 ERA in his first eight in 1941.	Carlos Beltran hit a solo homer -- his ninth -- for St. Louis. Pete Kozma added an RBI single and Jon Jay a sacrifice fly for the Cardinals
column19: who are National League-best 22-12.	Molina had two hits to extend his hitting streak to 10 games
column20: which is the longest for a Cardinal this season.	Rockies starter Jon Garland (2-3) gave up all three runs in five innings. Garland allowed seven hits and three walks while striking out five.	Garland retired the first five batters he faced before Jay singled to center with two outs in the second. David Freese walked
column21: and Kozma drove home Jay with a single to left.	Beltran made it 2-0 when he hit Garland's first pitch of the third inning 409 feet into the seats in right. Jay gave the Cardinals a three-run cushion with a sacrifice fly in the fifth.	Game notes	Dick Hughes and Scipio Spinks also struck out 13 for the Cardinals as rookies. ... Molina is batting .461 (18 for 39) during his hitting streak. ... Colorado has not won a series in St. Louis since sweeping four games from June 5-8
column22: 2009. ... Jay extended his hitting streak to seven games with his second-inning single. ... Garland is 1-6 with 6.61 ERA in his career against St. Louis. ... column1: PHOENIX --  Arizona Diamondbacks manager Kirk Gibson moved Miguel Montero down to eighth in the lineup
column2: hoping it would give him a spark
column3: playing a hunch that he might come up in a big situation.	He was right on both counts.	Hitting before the pitcher for the first time in two years
column4: Montero hit a tiebreaking homer off the right foul pole in the eighth inning
column5: helping the Diamondbacks beat the Philadelphia Phillies 3-2 Friday night for their fifth straight victory.	"One of the things when you're hitting eighth is that you have to tell yourself you might come up in a situation where you can do something good
column7: Gibson said. It was huge for us."	The Diamondbacks struggled most of the night against Phillies starter Tyler Cloyd
column8: managing two hits off him in 6 2/3 innings. They came through when he went out
column10: scoring on a run in the seventh when Martin Prado broke a 29 at-bat hitless streak with runners in scoring position
column11: then taking the lead when Montero hit the first pitch thrown by Mike Adams (1-3) in the eighth that curled toward the foul pole in right and just caught it.	Tony Sipp (2-1) got two outs in the eighth inning and David Hernandez worked out of a jam in the ninth for his first save
column12: sending Arizona to its sixth win in seven games.	"I knew the ball was gone
column13: but you have so much bad luck that I was running around and was like
column15: I can't believe that ball is going to go foul
column16: Montero said. I was fortunate enough to hit the pole. It feels great to help the team because I've been disappointed in myself not being able to the ball the way I wanted."	The Phillies jumped on Kennedy early
column17: starting with Rollins' 44th career leadoff homer that tied him with Brady Anderson for fourth all-time. They scored another run in the first inning
column18: but struggled the rest of the way against Kennedy and couldn't score against Hernandez with runners on second and third with one out in the ninth.	Laynce Nix made the second out in the ninth with a soft infield pop-up and Hernandez ended the game by getting Rollins to ground out to first.	"We broke through
column19: but we made some mistakes
column20: Phillies manager Charlie Manuel said. At the same time
column21: we got four hits in that (first) inning
column22: but we didn't capitalize on [a] better opportunity
column23: then we didn't add on during the game."	Kennedy has labored since beating St. Louis on Opening Day
column24: allowing four or more runs three times during a six-game winless streak. The right-hander lost to San Diego after allowing four runs in seven innings in his last outing and got off to a rough start against the Phillies.	Rollins hit the first pitch of the game out to right for his 44th career leadoff homer
column25: matching Brady Anderson for fourth all time. Domonic Brown followed a walk and another hit with a run-scoring single that put the Phillies up 2-0.	Kennedy found a rhythm after that
column26: allowing a single in the second inning and no other hits until Ben Revere led off the seventh with a single. He was lifted for a pinch hitter in the bottom half after allowing two runs on six hits with four strikeouts.	"It was his best outing of the season
column27: especially those last two innings
column28: Gibson said.	Cloyd was just as good.	The right-hander pitched six games for the Phillies in 2012, going 2-2, and opened this season in the minors.	He was called up to start against the Diamondbacks after Roy Halladay went out with a shoulder injury.	Making his season debut in one of baseball's most hitter-friendly parks didn't seem to bother the 25-year-old.	In the first inning, Eric Chavez lined a double to the right field corner off him and Paul Goldschmidt just beat John Mayberry's throw after running through -- almost literally -- third-base coach Matt Williams' stop sign.	Cloyd had the Diamondbacks guessing after that, working around a pair of walks in the fourth inning with a double play and allowing no hits until Cody Ross hit a one-out flare single to left in the seventh.	He was lifted after that, but didn't figure into the decision because Ross tagged up on Jason Kubel's long fly ball to get into scoring position and scored on Prado's run-scoring single off Antonio Bastardo.	Cloyd allowed two hits and struck out four, but is headed back to Triple-A Lehigh Valley. Right-hander Justin De Fratus will be called up to take his spot on the roster.	They told me no matter what happened tonight
column29: they were going to end up sending me down
column30: Cloyd said. I have to go down there and keep going
column31: keep myself in a position to come back up and help them out again."	Game notes	 Rollins' leadoff homer gave the Phillies 14 straight solo shots. ... Phillies RHP Roy Halladay

column1: SEATTLE --  With the blister on a finger of his pitching hand fully healed
column2: Hisashi Iwakuma felt he could throw basically any pitch he wanted in an impressive seven innings.	It looked much the same as his previous starts.	Iwakuma retired 16 straight over one stretch
column3: Raul Ibanez homered for the first time in nearly a month and the Seattle Mariners beat the Oakland Athletics 6-3 on Friday night.	"He repeats. He's so consistent with his delivery
column7: it's tough to see what is coming out
column8: Seattle manager Eric Wedge said. That's what you have to do. If you're going to be a solid starting pitcher up here
column9: you've got to do that."	Iwakuma (4-1) took a one-hitter into the sixth inning before running into trouble
column10: putting together another strong outing to help cement himself and Felix Hernandez as one of the top rotation duos in baseball. Iwakuma has allowed five earned runs over his past five starts
column11: and the number could have been even smaller if not for a scoring change that ended up tagging him with two earned runs against the A's.	Overshadowed by Hernandez
column12: the ace of the Mariners staff
column13: Iwakuma has been nearly as solid this season. He's pitched at least six innings in seven of eight starts despite being bothered by a lingering blister on his pitching hand
column14: and has not allowed more than three earned runs in any start.	"Those two have just been on another level
column15: Seattle third baseman Kyle Seager said. Everybody knows Felix
column16: obviously
column17: but (Iwakuma) he's been flying under the radar a little bit but he's been just as impressive. It's been pretty fun to play behind those two especially."	Iwakuma gave up a solid leadoff single to right field to John Jaso and then was unhittable for the next five innings. He set down 15 straight with remarkable ease
column18: through a combination of broken bats
column19: weak ground balls and lazy flies. He struck out Yoenis Cespedes to close the first
column20: struck out Derek Norris and Jaso in the third and retired Josh Donaldson and Daric Barton swinging to end the fifth.	Iwakuma's streak finally ended at 16 straight retired when Eric Sogard reached on an infield single -- originally ruled an error -- with one-out in the sixth inning. His ground ball bounced off the arm of shortstop Brendan Ryan and Sogard reached without a throw. Jaso followed with a bloop single
column21: and the A's finally got to Iwakuma on Jed Lowrie's two-out
column22: two-run double into the right-field corner. Lowrie had just one RBI in his previous 17 games before the double.	The scoring change cost Iwakuma a chance to have his ERA dip below Hernandez's for the best in the American League. Instead
column23: Iwakuma's ERA rose from 1.61 to 1.74. He gave up four hits
column24: struck out nine and walked none.  Tom Wilhelmsen pitched the ninth for his 10th save.	"It's a mental relief
column25: being able to pitch with that much of a big lead is big for myself
column26: so being able to pitch with a better rhythm helped me be able to go through seven innings
column27: Iwakuma said through an interpreter.	Seattle scored twice in the first off Oakland starter Dan Straily (1-1). Seattle broke the game open with Ibanez's three-run homer in the third inning that came with two outs.  Oakland lost its season-high fifth straight and dipped below .500 since starting the season 1-2. The A's fell to 2-6 on their current 10-game road trip and only once has Oakland scored more than three runs.	Everybody has to pick everybody up and we're not doing that right now
column28: Oakland manager Bob Melvin said.	Straily struggled to get through five innings, but didn't get help from his defense starting in the first inning that led to two runs. Kendrys Morales' chopper to left side bounced past both third baseman Josh Donaldson and Lowrie at shortstop to put runners at the corners with one out instead of a possible inning-ending double play. Michael Morse followed with an RBI single and Justin Smoak lined an RBI double to give Iwakuma an early lead.	Seattle's runs in the third also came thanks to a fortunate bounce. Seager reached on an infield single that spun awkwardly off the end of his bat. Straily gave up a two-out walk to Smoak that proved costly when Ibanez turned on a 1-1 pitch for his third homer of the season and first since April 14.	It's always nice to contribute and the last few games I've played I guess have been better
column29:
Ibanez said.	Game notes	 Seattle improved to 16-8 this season when its starting pitcher works at least six innings. They are 1-11 when the starter fails to get through six. ... Seager scored three of the four times he reached base. ... Oakland's Derek Norris hit a solo homer, his first of the season, in the eighth off Seattle reliever Oliver Perez. Marlins 5, Dodgers 4.
LOS ANGELES --  Derek Dietrich will always remember his first major league home run, and the fact that it was a timely hit for the Marlins was a bonus.	Dietrich tied the game with a three-run shot, Juan Pierre singled in the go-ahead run in the seventh inning and Miami dealt the Los Angeles Dodgers their eighth straight loss, 5-4 on Friday night.	The Marlins tied the game 3-all in the fourth on Dietrich's three-run homer with two outs. Placido Polanco and Marcell Ozuna sandwiched walks around a strikeout by Justin Ruggiano and a pop foul by Greg Dobbs before Dietrich sent a 3-2 pitch into the right field pavilion while playing in his second major league game.	How special
column30: Dietrich said. So many greats have played here. It kind of brings chills. I'm glad my family got to see it."	Miami ended its own three-game losing streak in the matchup of cellar dwellers. The Marlins have the NL's worst record at 11-25
column31: and got outscored 11-1 during a three-game sweep in San Diego.	"We've been waiting on a big hit
column32: Marlins manager Mike Redmond said. Got a young kid up there who's taking advantage of an opportunity."	Rookie Jose Fernandez (2-2) allowed three runs and eight hits in six innings
column33: struck out seven and walked two for his second major league win
column34: having won at Philadelphia last weekend.	"I keep learning every start
column35: he said.	Fernandez threw 17 consecutive strikes at one point in the game.	He's one of those guys that you want to get to early because
column37: he's going to get better as the game goes on
column38: Dodgers manager Don Mattingly said. He was aggressive in the strike zone and he wasn't afraid of anybody. He was coming right after us."	Steve Cishek pitched the ninth to earn his fifth save in six chances.	Former Dodger Pierre singled to left field in the seventh
column39: giving Miami a 4-3 lead. Adeiny Hechavarria grounded into a double play
column40: scoring pinch-hitter Chris Coghlan
column41: who doubled off the top of the wall in center field. The umpires reviewed the play and upheld second base ump Chris Guccione's original call after Marlins manager Mike Redmond came out to discuss it.	"It was a big play at the time and I just wanted to make sure they got it right
column42: and they did
column43: Redmond said.	The Dodgers blew an early lead for the second straight game in equaling their longest skid since dropping eight in a row from Aug. 22-29, 2008. Five of the losses have been at home, tying their longest such skid since May 28-June 11 last year.	At 13-21, the Dodgers are last in the NL West and have yet to win in May. Mattingly is facing rampant speculation about his future with his high-priced lineup failing to contend.	Ronald Belisario (2-4) took the loss, giving up two runs and three hits in one-plus innings. He walked one and struck out none.	The Dodgers have scored three runs or less seven times during their skid. Sluggers Matt Kemp and Andre Ethier continued to slump, combining to go 1 for 8. Kemp struck out twice.	Rookie Matt Magill made his third career start for the Dodgers, giving up three runs and five hits in five innings. He struck out two and walked four in his second straight poor outing. The right-hander didn't make it out of the second inning last weekend at San Francisco.	Los Angeles closed to 5-4 in the eighth when A.J. Ellis singled in Kemp, who led off with a single and stole second. They had the tying run on third when Dee Gordon grounded out to second base to end the inning.	The Dodgers loaded the bases with two outs in the sixth, but pinch-hitter Tim Federowicz flied out to center to end the inning.	After trailing early, Redmond noticed a change in Fernandez.	He came out up in the zone in the first and then he turned it up after that and was lights out
column44: the manager said. He pounded the strike zone and kept guys off-balance."	The Dodgers staked Magill to a 3-0 lead in the first on Adrian Gonzalez's three-run homer. Carl Crawford led off with a single and Nick Punto walked to set up Gonzalez. They led 2-0 on Wednesday and ended up losing 3-2 to Arizona.	Fernandez said that his first pitch after the homer "I felt like now I'm pitching. I'm young and trying to get adjusted to the game."	Game notes	 Dodgers RHP Zack Greinke and LHP Scott Elbert made their first rehab appearances for Single-A Rancho Cucamonga in its game at Lake Elsinore on Friday night. Greinke allowed eight runs -- three earned -- and six hits in 4 1/3 innings
column45: struck out four and walked none. He broke his left collarbone in a bench-clearing brawl at San Diego last month. Elbert was expected to throw one inning of relief while rehabbing from left elbow surgery. ... Marlins INF Chris Valaika had two pins inserted in his left wrist Friday in Miami. He's expected to be out six to eight weeks. ... The Marlins shuffled their rotation for Sunday's series finale. RHP Tom Koehler will start in place of LHP Wade LeBlanc. ... The Dodgers selected the contract of OF/1B Scott Van Slyke from Triple-A Albuquerque and optioned IF/OF Elian Herrera back to Albuquerque three days after he had been called up. They also transferred RHP Chad Billingsley to the 60-day DL. He had Tommy John surgery on April 24.	Randy Arozarena celebrates with his family at home after learning he won the 2021 AL Rookie of the Year.	From MVP to Cy Young and more
column46: this is your one-stop shop as baseball's 2021 hardware is handed out.	Randy Arozarena hit 20 home runs and stole 20 bases this season
column47: leading all rookies with a 4.1 WAR.	Take a look back at the best plays from NL Rookie of the Year Jonathan India's 2021 campaign.	Julio Lugo
column48: who played for seven teams in a 12-year major league career
column49: has died. He was 45.	Jonathan India finished ahead of Cardinals OF Dylan Carlson and Marlins starter Trevor Rogers.

column1: SAN FRANCISCO --  Facing Tim Hudson usually means bad news for the San Francisco Giants.	They turned the tables Friday night in an 8-2 victory over the Atlanta Braves
column2: beating the veteran right-hander for the first time in seven years.	The Giants drove Hudson from the game in a six-run fourth inning that represented their biggest rally of the season.	That support proved plenty for Matt Cain (2-2)
column3: who went eight innings and turned in his second straight stellar outing after going winless over his first six starts.	The Giants' ace allowed just three hits and chipped in with an RBI single during the six-run rally. His effort was badly needed for a rotation that came in having posted just 16 quality starts in 35 games.	"When you get some run support like I did tonight
column4: against a guy that's done what he's done in his career
column6: Cain said. It's always a battle with him."	The Giants hadn't beaten Hudson since April 8
column8: a span during which he was 6-0 with a 2.48 ERA against San Francisco.	Hudson (4-2) was cruising until the fourth
column9: when the Giants batted around and scored six runs. That rally featured two hits by Marco Scutaro
column10: including a two-run single.	Buster Posey split the left-center gap with an RBI double to kick-start things. Hunter Pence dribbled an infield single to score another and Brandon Belt chopped a run-scoring double over Atlanta first baseman Freddie Freeman.	Brandon Crawford was intentionally walked with one out to load the bases for Cain
column11: who stepped to the plate 0-for-11 on the season. He grounded a single through the right side to make it 4-0
column12: and Scutaro capped the rally with a two-run single to left to drive Hudson from the game.	The six runs and seven hits were the most the Giants have managed in any single inning this season. Hudson tied his season high with six runs allowed in 3 2/3 innings
column13: his shortest outing of the season.	"Obviously
column15: Hudson said. I made very good pitches to get the inning going and then it seemed when I needed a break here or there
column16: their balls just found some holes. I had a hard time stopping the bleeding."	The Braves did their only damage off Cain when Brian McCann crushed a two-run homer to right in the fifth. It marked the 26th time an opponent knocked one into McCovey Cove on the fly
column17: and it was the 88th "splash hit" overall since AT&T Park opened in 2000.	Cain delivered his best start of the season despite taking a liner off his hip from the bat of McCann in the second. He recovered and chased the ball down by the first-base line and got the out.	"What a great job
column18: a clutch job
column19: Giants manager Bruce Bochy said. We needed a lot of length from our starter tonight and he did more than that. Eight solid innings -- especially after getting hit."	McCann was the bright spot for Atlanta. After missing the first 31 games of the season while recovering from shoulder surgery
column20: he's 5-for-16 with two homers and seven RBI in four games.	"I've felt good since spring training and I carried it into the season and on my rehab stints
column21: McCann said.	Game notes	 Scutaro has a 10-game hitting streak during which he's hitting .487 (19-for-39). However, his sore back acted up during the game and Bochy wasn't sure if the second baseman would play Saturday. ... Struggling Giants right-hander Ryan Vogelsong will make his next start as scheduled Wednesday at Toronto, Bochy said. There was speculation that Vogelsong, 1/3 with a 7.78 ERA, might be skipped for a turn.  ... Madison Bumgarner, who takes the ball Saturday against Atlanta, has received just four runs of support over his past four starts. ... Carlos Tosca served as the Braves' interim manager Friday in place of Fredi Gonzalez and will do so again Saturday, with Gonzalez in Georgia to attend his daughter's college graduation. ... Right fielder Jason Heyward did not play Friday for Triple-A Gwinnett, one day after beginning a rehab assignment following his emergency appendectomy April 22. GM Frank Wren said Heyward was experiencing normal soreness" after the long layoff. ... Left-hander Paul Maholm
column23: is 2-2 with a 3.43 ERA in nine career starts against the Giants.	Detroit got a jump-start on the winter signings
column24: landing lefty Eduardo Rodriguez. We break down the deal.	In a free-agent field filled with future Hall of Famers
column25: Detroit added one of the most undervalued pitchers available this winter.	Joon Lee breaks down how Eduardo Rodriguez signing with Detroit affects the Tigers and Red Sox.	Check out some of the most electric moments from Vladimir Guerrero Jr.'s career.	Former Boston Red Sox left-hander Eduardo Rodriguez and the Detroit Tigers are in agreement on a five-year deal worth $77 million

column1: SAN FRANCISCO -- Madison Bumgarner didn't take any personal satisfaction from his first career victory over the Atlanta Braves.	There's no doubt what it meant to his team.	Bumgarner struck out a season-high 11 over seven innings
column2: Gregor Blanco entered in the fifth as a pinch hitter and drove in four runs
column3: and the San Francisco Giants routed the Atlanta Braves 10-1 on Saturday.	The North Carolina native grew up rooting for the Braves and had been winless against them in four previous starts. Bumgarner (4-1) gave up just four hits and walked two
column4: winning for the first time since April 13.	"They've got as good a shot as anybody to play October baseball
column5: Bumgarner said of the Braves. When you play a team like that
column6: you want to play your best baseball
column7: too."	Blanco had a three-run double and triple in setting a career high for RBIs.	San Francisco's rotation
column8: considered one of the best in the majors
column9: has struggled early this season. But ace Matt Cain tossed eight innings of three-hit ball in Friday's win
column11: the Giants can claim the four-game series with a victory in Sunday's finale.	It was a frustrating day for the National League East-leading Braves. Dan Uggla struck out four times and Chris Johnson went down swinging three times. After a victory in Thursday's opener
column12: the Braves have mustered just 10 hits and been outscored 18-3.	"He's nasty
column14: he is one of the best lefties in the game. He throws his cutter in to righties. He makes righties feel uneasy."	They hurt themselves defensively Saturday
column15: and lefty Paul Maholm (4-4) lasted just 4 1/3 innings and was charged with six runs on eight hits.	The Giants led 2-1 when they broke the game open with a four-run fifth
column16: aided by the adventures of Braves right fielder Justin Upton.	Upton let Marco Scutaro's liner skip past him for a one-out triple. After Pablo Sandoval was hit by a pitch
column17: Buster Posey drove an RBI double deep to right that Upton made an awkward attempt on as it bounced up against the wall. Hunter Pence was intentionally walked to load the bases
column18: and Braves interim manager Carlos Tosca called on Cory Gearrin to relieve Maholm.	Giants manager Bruce Bochy sent up Blanco to hit for Francisco Peguero
column19: and Blanco delivered a three-run double to right-center that extended the Giants' lead to 6-1.	"It is definitely a difficult outfield
column20: Upton said. You definitely have to make a decision pre-pitch on how aggressive you want to be."	Blanco was at it again in the eighth
column21: when the Giants batted around and tacked on four more. His liner to left field skipped past a charging Evan Gattis and went for an RBI triple. Blanco is 9 for 19 this season with runners in scoring position.	San Francisco's starting pitchers entered the day with a 4.48 ERA
column22: which ranked 13th out of 15 NL teams. Bumgarner rebounded after his worst outing of the season
column23: when he gave up five runs in six innings against Philadelphia on Monday.	"That's a tough lineup to go through and he did quite a job for us
column24: Bochy said.	Johnson, the Braves third baseman, struck out swinging in all three at-bats against Bumgarner.	He's nasty
column25: Johnson said. For me
column26: he is one of the best lefties in the game. He throws his cutter in to righties. He makes righties feel uneasy."	Sandoval's homer in the first gave the Giants an early lead. Brandon Crawford doubled in a run in the fourth to make it 2-0
column27: one of two hits the left-handed hitting Crawford had off Maholm.	Maholm entered Saturday having yielded just four hits to lefties all season.	Game notes	Giants reliever Santiago Casilla was scheduled to run during batting practice to test his sore right knee
column28: but Bochy wasn't planning on having Casilla available until Tuesday's road trip opener at Toronto. ... Tim Lincecum
column29: who starts Sunday for San Francisco
column30: has lost his last four starts against Atlanta. Kris Medlen will take the ball for the Braves
column31: looking to snap a five-start winless streak. ... Scutaro has an 11-game hitting streak. ... Johnson is 0 for 17 with eight strikeouts this month.	Randy Arozarena celebrates with his family at home after learning he won the 2021 AL Rookie of the Year.	From MVP to Cy Young and more

column1: CINCINNATI -- Jay Bruce has been getting pitches to hit all season. Lately
column2: he's doing something with them.	Bruce homered his first time up
column3: then doubled twice during a seven-run burst as the Cincinnati Reds delighted a sellout crowd
column4: battering the Milwaukee Brewers 13-7 on Saturday.	"It's a long season
column5: said Bruce, who's hit just three homers after leading the Reds with 34 last season. I'm trying to get pitches to hit. Lately
column6: I've been missing them less."	Manager Dusty Baker has seen his two-time All-Star starting to put it together.	"I told Jay he's on his way
column7: Baker said. You could tell the way he's been swinging the bat the last couple of days."	Six different Reds players drove in two runs each
column8: including starting pitcher Mat Latos (4-0).	Baker never is comfortable against the hard-hitting Brewers.	"You've got to get a lot of run support
column9: said Baker, whose defending NL Central champions moved five games over .500 for the first time this season. Those guys can hit. You've got to keep scoring and scoring and scoring."	The bottom five hitters in Cincinnati's lineup were a combined 8-for-9 in the first three innings
column10: scoring 10 runs and driving in six against Hiram Burgos (1-1). The rookie allowed 12 runs on 11 hits and three walks in those three innings.	"You feel kind of bad for the kid
column11: but you can't be called off
column12: Baker said. You could tell it was going to be one of those-high scoring games."	Milwaukee manager Ron Roenicke felt as if he had no choice but to leave Burgos in the game.	"I don't ever want to do that to somebody again
column13: he said. We're hurting in the bullpen."	A promotion featuring Aroldis Chapman bobbleheads drew a crowd of 41
column14: 678. The Reds never needed their closer after romping early.	Bruce led off a five-run second that was helped by a pair of fielding mistakes by left fielder Ryan Braun. Bruce opened the seven-run third with a double and capped it with an RBI double that made it 12-4.	Bruce became the first Reds player with two hits in one inning since Drew Stubbs on April 25
column16: at Milwaukee and the first Reds player with two doubles in one inning since Sean Casey on Aug. 7
column18: also against Milwaukee.	Latos won his fourth straight start. He allowed a total of 14 runs in his previous seven starts
column19: but gave up seven in this win
column20: including solo homers by Jean Segura and Norichika Aoki.	"Give the `W' to the offense
column21: a plainly disgusted Latos said. They deserve it. I felt all right. I didn't allow myself to have my best stuff. I was aggravated with myself. It was a poor performance."	Latos got two hits and scored twice.	"I could't care less
column22: he said. I gave up seven runs. ... I couldn't care less about the hits."	Latos almost didn't last long enough to qualify for the win
column23: Baker said.	"I was tempted (to pull Latos) in the fifth
column25: `You're about to blow this victory.' We helped him."	Latos gave up a homer to Segura with one out in the first and Aramis Ramirez hit an RBI double off the wall later in the inning.	Baker believes the Brewers are even more dangerous with Segura
column26: who's in his first full season with Milwaukee after being acquired from the Angels in the Zack Greinke deal last July.	"With Segura
column27: you've got to score even more
column28: Baker said. He's a heck of a player. That was a heck of a trade."	After Bruce opened the Reds' second with a 437-foot homer for his second shot in three games
column29: Braun allowed what looked like an easy fly ball by Xavier Paul to drop behind him for a two-base error. Braun later overthrew the cutoff man on Zack Cozart's sacrifice fly
column30: allowing runners to advance and setting up Joey Votto's RBI groundout.	Milwaukee got two runs back in the third on Braun's RBI double and Ramirez's run-scoring single
column31: but the Reds pulled away in the bottom half.	Cincinnati's spree included Latos' RBI groundball single up the middle through a drawn-in infield.	Aoki added his fourth homer of the season in the sixth.	Game notes	The win clinched the three-game series for the Reds
column32: giving them six wins in seven home series this season. ... Reds OF Chris Heisey is scheduled to start a rehab assignment Monday at Double-A Pensacola. Heisey has been on the disabled list since April 29 with a strained right hamstring. ... For the first time in franchise history

column2: Fla. -- One swing of Evan Longoria's bat erased another night of frustration for the Tampa Bay Rays.	Longoria hit a two-run homer with two outs in the bottom of the ninth inning off Padres closer Huston Street on Saturday night
column3: rallying the Rays to an 8-7 victory over San Diego.	Street (0-2) retired the first two batters in the ninth before walking Ben Zobrist on a full count. Longoria followed with his ninth home run
column4: handing Street his first blown save in nine tries this season.	"You need games like this
column5: whether it's myself or anybody coming through in the clutch
column6: to kind of boost morale and jump-start everything
column7: Longoria said.	Failing to finish off Zobrist is what bothered Street the most.	You get him 1-2
column8: you've got to make a pitch
column9: he said. I'm frustrated about that just as much as leaving a pitch to Longoria in the middle of the plate."	It was the fourth straight win for the Rays
column10: who had to come back after Jesus Guzman's pinch-hit grand slam off Jeremy Hellickson helped San Diego overcame a 6-2 deficit in the seventh. If the Padres had held on
column11: it would have been the 14th game the Rays lost this season after leading. They had lost twice this week after taking big leads into the late innings.	"It would have been among the top three worst losses of the year
column12: said manager Joe Maddon, who was uncharacteristically perturbed about another blown lead.	That's not going to happen very often
column13: Maddon said. We were fortunate Longo was in the right spot
column14: fortunate that Zo gets it as a hitter. You had all this talent coming together at that particular moment. But you can't go to the dance playing like that. When you get leads
column15: you've got to put the other team away. I'm not happy with that. That's inappropriate. That's got to stop."	Cesar Ramos (1-0) got the win as the Rays moved up to .500 for the first time since April 7.	James Loney hit a two-run homer as the Rays roughed up San Diego's Burch Smith in the second inning of his major league debut. The Rays scored six runs on five hits and a couple of walks in the inning and drove Smith out of the game.	"I feel the difference between the first and second inning was I was locating the fastball better. The second inning I was leaving pitches over the plate
column16: said Smith. Hitters at this level are going to take advantage of mistakes. (I'll) come back next time and do better."	Hellickson retired 16 straight batters after giving up three hits
column17: including Chase Headley's two-run homer
column18: in the first.	Hellickson took a four-run lead into the seventh
column19: when he walked Carlos Quentin to start the Padres' rally. After Guzman's slam
column20: Quentin walked again in the same inning
column21: this time with the bases loaded against Jamey Wright to force in the lead run that made it 7-6.	"It was a huge blow at the time
column23: Longoria said. We stayed in the game
column24: continued to have good at bats
column25: and we're happy to get the results that we did."	Smith
column26: a 23-year-old righty called up from Double-A San Antonio
column27: got three quick outs
column28: including a couple of strikeouts in his first inning. But he walked Longoria to lead off the second and Loney followed with his second homer of the season. Smith threw 26 pitches in the inning without getting an out. Tyson Ross finished the inning for the Padres and pitched four shutout innings of relief.	Hellickson pitched 6 2/3 innings
column29: giving up six earned runs on six hits while striking out eight. He has had leads in each of his last four starts
column30: but has not won any of them.	Game notes	San Diego optioned RHP Brad Boxberger to Triple-A Tucson to open a roster spot for Smith. Boxberger appeared in two games for the Padres. .... Padres LHP Clayton Richard
column31: recovering from an intestinal virus and eligible to come off the disabled list on May 20
column32: will pitch for Triple-A Tucson in a rehab game on Thursday . . . Rays CF and leadoff hitter Desmond Jennings was out of the lineup for the second straight night. Manager Joe Maddon said he's simply giving Jennings
column33: who's batting .244 and has a season-best seven-game hitting streak
column34: some rest. "I think with a little respite
column35: this guy is going to be even better when he comes back. There's nothing wrong. I just want to give him a break
column36:
Maddon said. Sam Fuld made his second straight start in center field. . . . Smith was the 443rd player drafted in 2011 and the ninth to make it to the majors. DETROIT -- On a night when it seemed the 27th out might never come for the Cleveland Indians, Chris Perez threw one last fastball to Miguel Cabrera and hoped the Detroit slugger would hit it on the ground.	He chopped it
column37: Perez said. I wanted him to put something in play
column38: but down. Luckily
column39: he did."	Perez got Cabrera to hit a game-ending groundout with two on in the ninth inning
column40: and Cleveland held on for a 7-6 win over the Tigers on Saturday night. Ubaldo Jimenez outpitched Justin Verlander
column41: but Detroit's late rally forced the Indians to sweat out a tense finish.	Perez came on to pitch the ninth with Cleveland ahead 7-5. He was in a jam after a one-out error by first baseman Nick Swisher and a single by Omar Infante
column42: but second baseman Jason Kipnis made a sparkling play behind second
column43: fielding Austin Jackson's grounder up the middle and flipping behind his back to shortstop Asdrubal Cabrera for a force.	"Awesome -- that saved me
column44: Perez said. It made up for Swish's play. Baseball kind of works out that way. He picked me up."	That was out No. 26. The Indians still needed one more
column45: and Torii Hunter's RBI single gave Miguel Cabrera another trip to the plate with men on first and second.	The count ran from 0-2 to 3-2
column46: but Cabrera -- who entered the day leading the majors in batting average and RBIs -- hit a slow grounder to third to end it.	It was Perez's sixth save.	"We fought tooth and nail to get the right guy up there
column47: Tigers manager Jim Leyland said. I'll take that situation every time
column48: but even that guy can't come through every time. We just put ourselves in too big a hole."	Verlander (4-3) was erratic early
column49: allowing three runs in the first two innings. He settled down a bit after that
column50: but the Indians took a 6-1 lead before Detroit closed the gap with a four-run seventh.	Jimenez (3-2) allowed a run and three hits in six innings
column51: striking out eight with one walk. He's won three straight starts for the first time since the Indians acquired him in a trade in 2011.	Jhonny Peralta hit a solo homer for Detroit.	Swisher opened the scoring with an RBI double in the first
column52: and Jason Giambi drew a bases-loaded walk to make it 2-0. That was Verlander's third walk of the first inning.	The Detroit ace got the first two outs of the second but allowed another run when Kipnis hit a single and Asdrubal Cabrera followed with a double.	"My fastball control just wasn't good at all
column53: Verlander said. I was trying to get ahead with the fastball and then throw off-speed stuff
column54: hoping I could grind out six innings
column55: but I didn't even do that."	Verlander allowed six hits and five walks in five innings
column56: striking out seven and leaving after 110 pitches. After Peralta's homer got the Tigers on the board in the third
column57: Cleveland added an unearned run off Verlander in the fifth to make it 4-1.	Swisher walked to lead off that inning
column58: and Carlos Santana hit what looked like a double play grounder to first baseman Prince Fielder
column59: who stepped on first and threw to second to trap Swisher between bases. Miguel Cabrera
column61: was involved in the rundown because a defensive shift had him playing close to second
column62: and he threw the ball away for an error. Swisher eventually scored on a two-out single by Mark Reynolds.	Asdrubal Cabrera's RBI single in the sixth made it 5-1
column63: and pinch-hitter Mike Aviles added a run-scoring single of his own in the seventh
column64: but the Cleveland bullpen almost gave up the lead. Jimenez left after 93 pitches
column65: and Nick Hagadone allowed a double and two walks to start the Detroit seventh.	Cody Allen came on and allowed a sacrifice fly to pinch-hitter Brayan Pena. Infante added a two-run triple and scored on Jackson's groundout to make it 6-5.	A sacrifice fly by Giambi in the eighth gave Cleveland an insurance run the Indians would end up needing.	When Jimenez was acquired two years ago
column66: the Indians hoped they were getting an ace who could help them compete with teams like the Tigers. The right-hander hasn't come close to expectations
column67: but he's pitching better now.	"I think it's all about my mechanics
column68: Jimenez said. I think the last three games I've been able to repeat my mechanics with every pitch."	This was Cleveland's seventh game this season against a former Cy Young Award winner
column69: and the Indians are 6-1 in those games.	Game notes	It rained a bit early in the game
column70: but not hard enough to halt play. ... Peralta and Miguel Cabrera extended their hitting streaks to 10 games. ... Fielder was hit in the left thigh in the eighth and went hobbling toward the mound
column71: but he wasn't charging reliever Joe Smith. He was just trying to run through the pain a bit and his momentum took him in the direction of the pitcher. ... Jimenez's previous three-start winning streak was in July 2011
column72: less than a month before the trade to Cleveland. ... The Indians have not lost any of their last six series. The rubber game of this three-game set is Sunday
column73: with Cleveland's Zach McAllister (3-3) facing Detroit's Rick Porcello (1-2).	From MVP to Cy Young and more
column74: this is your one-stop shop as baseball's 2021 hardware is handed out.	Jonathan India finished ahead of Cardinals OF Dylan Carlson and Marlins starter Trevor Rogers for NL Rookie of the Year.	The Yankees hired former Mets manager Luis Rojas as their new third-base coach on Monday.	Detroit got a jump-start on the winter signings
column75: landing lefty Eduardo Rodriguez. We break down the deal.	In a free-agent field filled with future Hall of Famers
column76: Detroit added one of the most undervalued pitchers available this winter.	Joon Lee breaks down how Eduardo Rodriguez signing with Detroit affects the Tigers and Red Sox.

column2: Mike Trout is showing signs of getting back to his dominant 2012 form.	Trout hit a two-run homer and Jerome Williams pitched into the seventh inning to help the Los Angeles Angels beat the Chicago White Sox 3-2 on Saturday night.	Williams (2-1) allowed two runs and scattered seven hits in 6 2/3 innings. He struck out three and walked one. After eight appearances out of the bullpen
column3: Williams made his second start after he replaced the struggling Garrett Richards
column4: who was filling in for injured Los Angeles ace Jered Weaver.	Alberto Callaspo led off the game with a bloop single
column6: Trout put the Angels ahead with a two-run shot to left for his sixth of the season. The home run was Trout's fourth in 10 games.	"It was about 130 games last year he was pretty good. You're not going to be locked in all the time
column7: but there is no doubt he is finding a comfort zone in the box and it is good to see him drive the ball
column8: said Scioscia.	White Sox starter Jose Quintana (2-1) allowed three runs in the loss. He gave up five hits and struck out five.	The Angels tied a season-high three-game winning streak, but are currently nine games behind the Rangers in the AL West and are finally showing signs of getting back to the top of the standings.	Everything is getting back to normal
column9: playing like how we are supposed to be playing baseball. Everybody is doing their jobs
column10: shut-down innings and everyone is swinging the bat. Everything is turning around now
column11: Williams said.	Scott Downs got one out in the seventh, Richards pitched a perfect eighth and Ernesto Frieri pitched a scoreless ninth for his seventh save in eight chances.	I think the one thing you can point to is our bullpen. Our bullpen has responded to the challenge of getting outs that we need
column12: said Scioscia.	It was Williams' first win as a starter since June 1, 2012 against the Rangers.	I didn't really have my best stuff but I battled through it any way possible
column13: said Williams.	The White Sox, who committed three errors, have lost eight of its last 12 games.	Everybody's working. It's a tough thing sometimes
column14: White Sox first baseman Paul Konerko said. This year
column15: it's been the mistakes we make
column16: the hits we don't get. It's coming from a place of trying too hard."	The White Sox loaded the bases in the second inning. With two outs
column17: Tyler Greene hit a slow roller to shortstop Brendan Harris. Harris fielded the ball while moving to his left
column18: but his throw to first was off-balanced and late
column19: allowing Paul Konerko to score. Alejandro De Aza followed with an RBI single to right to tie the game
column20: Jeff Keppinger tried to score from second on De Aza's single but was thrown out at the plate by Josh Hamilton.	The Angels got the lead back in the third inning thanks to an error and a passed ball.	With two outs
column21: Hamilton hit a routine grounder to Greene at second base. Greene made a lackadaisical throw to first base that got away from Dunn. Albert Pujols
column23: advanced to third on Greene's throwing error. Pujols later scored when catcher Tyler Flowers couldn't keep Quintana's pitch to Howie Kendrick in front of him. On Flowers' flip
column24: Quintana had a shot to tag Pujols at the plate
column25: but Pujols avoided the tag with his slide.	The three errors in the game for the White Sox tied the Angels for most errors in the American League with 27.	"I don't think that's anything mental. Not being in the right position or things like that. Physical stuff
column26: you get. But you know it's just one of those that you do have to do it better. It's that simple
column27:
said White Sox manager Robin Ventura.	Game notes	 White Sox INF Conor Gillaspie was scratched from the White Sox lineup due to an upper respiratory infection. Keppinger moved to third base and Greene started at second base. ... Angels reliever Ryan Madson (Tommy John recovery) threw one inning in an extended-spring training game on Saturday. Angels manager Mike Scioscia was encouraged with Madson's velocity, which was between 91-94 mph. He will pitch again on Monday then receive his minor league rehab assignment. ... INF Erick Aybar missed his second straight game with tightness in his right hamstring. ... By taking the first two games of the series, the Angels won its third series of the season. ... Dunn struck out three times to drop his average to .137.	Detroit got a jump-start on the winter signings, landing lefty Eduardo Rodriguez. We break down the deal.	In a free-agent field filled with future Hall of Famers, Detroit added one of the most undervalued pitchers available this winter.	Joon Lee breaks down how Eduardo Rodriguez signing with Detroit affects the Tigers and Red Sox.	Check out some of the most electric moments from Vladimir Guerrero Jr.'s career.	Former Boston Red Sox left-hander Eduardo Rodriguez and the Detroit Tigers are in agreement on a five-year deal worth $77 million, sources confirmed to ESPN.	From who we think deserves MVP and Cy Young to if the voters got it right, this is your one-stop shop as baseball's 2021 hardware is handed out.
