column1: TORONTO -- Jose Bautista is one dangerous hitter
column2: and he loves to come to the plate with the game on the line.	Bautista homered twice and drove in the winning run with a 10th-inning single
column3: leading the Toronto Blue Jays to a 4-3 victory over the Tampa Bay Rays on Wednesday.	"He's not just a slugger; he's a complete hitter
column4: Blue Jays manager John Gibbons said. He can do a lot of things with that bat."	The two-time major league home run champion said he thrives on hitting in key situations.	"I get a little more excited for those
column5: Bautista said. It was a huge moment and I'm just glad I was able to get the ball through that hole and drive in the winning run."	Bautista went 4-for-4 with a walk and four RBIs. Three other players had one hit
column6: but that was it for Toronto's offense.	"He was the reason we won the game today
column7: Blue Jays starter Mark Buehrle said.	Facing Cesar Ramos (1-1), Colby Rasmus reached on an infield single to begin the 10th. Rasmus moved to second on Emilio Bonifacio's sacrifice, then took third on Munenori Kawasaki's grounder. Pinch-hitter Mark DeRosa walked and Kyle Farnsworth came on to face Bautista, who fell behind 0-2 before lining a single into shallow right for the Blue Jays' first game-ending hit of the season.	The win is huge
column8: Bautista said. We're obviously excited. Any time you have a walk-off win
column9: it's exciting."	Aaron Loup (2-3) pitched one inning for the win as Toronto took two of three to win a series against Tampa Bay for the first time since August 2010. The Rays had won their past 15 series against the Blue Jays.	"It was pretty important to us
column10: Bautista said. It's a division game against a team that we haven't won a series against in a long time."	The teams were tied at 2 before Tampa Bay got a run in the ninth. Evan Longoria hit a one-out double off closer Casey Janssen
column11: extending his hitting streak to 16 games. James Loney followed with an RBI single.	But Fernando Rodney couldn't nail down the save
column12: yielding a leadoff home run to Bautista in the bottom half. It was Rodney's fourth blown save in 13 opportunities.	"I think I made a good pitch and he hit a good pitch
column13: Rodney said. When you have a type of hitter like that
column15: and you make a good pitch and they hit your best pitch
column16: there's nothing you can do."	The Rays have blown 28 leads this season
column17: including four in the ninth inning.	"It's been kind of difficult
column18: Rays manager Joe Maddon said. That was another one that got away. Everybody is doing their best
column19: they're trying. It's just not working out."	Bautista's 11th homer helped Janssen avoid his first loss since April 26
column21: at Baltimore. Bautista said he feels comfortable facing Rodney
column22: who had 48 saves in 50 chances last year
column23: but refused to explain why.	"I think I have a different approach than everybody else
column24: Bautista said. I feel pretty comfortable at the plate when he's on the mound. That's pretty much all I can say about that."	Bautista also hit a leadoff drive in the fourth off Jeremy Hellickson. It was his second multihomer game of the season and No. 19 for his career.	"Bautista had himself a pretty good day today
column25: Maddon said.	Toronto is the first team in the majors this season to have three players with 10 or more home runs. Edwin Encarnacion has 12 and J.P. Arencibia has 10.	Rodney got Encarnacion to ground out but was replaced after walking Adam Lind. Joel Peralta came on and sent it to extra innings by fanning Arencibia and retiring Brett Lawrie on a foulout.	Hellickson bounced back after giving up career highs of eight runs and 10 hits against Baltimore in his last outing. He allowed two runs and four hits in a season-high eight innings.	He did really well
column26: Maddon said. That was more like Helly tonight."	Anthony Gose doubled on Hellickson's first pitch of the game and scored when Bautista followed with a single. But Bautista was thrown out trying to advance to second on Encarnacion's fly ball to left
column27: and Hellickson set down his next seven batters.	The Rays took advantage of an error by second baseman Maicer Izturis to score two runs in the third. column28: allowing Molina to score. Ben Zobrist followed with an RBI single.	The Blue Jays tied it again

column1: CLEVELAND -- Justin Verlander wasn't about to let a win slip away in the rain.	Verlander returned to the mound after sitting through a 62-minute rain delay to get his fifth win and Miguel Cabrera hit another homer -- maybe the luckiest of his career -- as the Detroit Tigers beat the Cleveland Indians 11-7 on Wednesday night
column2: sweeping the two-game series between the AL Central's top teams.	Verlander (5-4) was two outs from qualifying for a victory when the game was stopped with the Tigers leading 9-5 in the fifth. The right-hander came back after the weather break and finished the inning to get the win
column3: ending a run of five straight victories by the Indians over former Cy Young winners.	Tigers manager Jim Leyland said his general rule is not let a pitcher return after sitting more than an hour. However
column4: he made an exception because it was so close
column5: and because Verlander is Verlander.	"Since I've been here
column7: Leyland. He has earned that right. I thought he deserved it."	After the long delay in the fifth

column10: held on to move within one-half game of the first-place Indians.	After the second rain delay

column19: but the five-time All-Star wasn't about to let a win slip away because of the weather.	While the grounds crew hauled out the tarp to cover the field in the fifth

column21: the crew chief working second base. Verlander was aware a possible victory was being washed away since he would likely not be coming back after the delay.	As the tarp was still being rolled up nearly an hour later

column1: PITTSBURGH -- Francisco Liriano's fastball is going where he wants it to. The Pittsburgh Pirates are following suit.	The veteran left-hander continued his torrid start
column2: scattering two hits over seven innings and the Pirates edged the Chicago Cubs 1-0 on Wednesday night.	Liriano (3-0) struck out nine and walked just one to remain unbeaten since making his season debut against the New York Mets two weeks ago.	"What was it
column4: nine punchouts and two hits?" Pittsburgh manager Clint Hurdle said. "Man
column5: that's clean stuff."	You won't find the Cubs arguing after Liriano escaped a bases-loaded
column6: no-out jam in the third inning unscathed and then cruised. The Cubs went 0-for-6 with runners in scoring position and are hitting just .160 (4-for-25) with runners on base during their three-game losing streak.	"It's the same old song and dance
column7: Chicago manager Dale Sveum said. We get people on but can't get them in."	Mark Melancon survived a bumpy ninth inning for his first save of the season. The Pirates were forced to sit closer Jason Grilli -- whose 18 saves lead the majors -- after he labored through 34 pitches in a 5-4 win on Tuesday.	The road to Melancon's first save since Aug. 26
column9: while pitching for Boston wasn't exactly smooth.	The Cubs put runners on first and second with one out but couldn't tie things up. Melancon
column10: who has served as the primary setup man this season
column11: didn't feel any extra jitters getting the last three outs.	"I do it every night
column12: it's just in the eighth inning instead of the ninth
column13: Melancon said.	Andrew McCutchen doubled twice for the Pirates and scored the game's only run on an RBI single by Garrett Jones in the first. Pittsburgh has won 10 of 12 to move 10 games above .500 (28-18). The Pirates have also won six straight one-run games.	I love the way we're going about our business
column14: Hurdle said.	Chicago's Jeff Samardzija (2-6) nearly matched Liriano pitch for pitch, giving up just three hits in seven innings, but received little help once again.	The Cubs have scored just 10 runs in Samardzija's losses. The right-hander's only issue came in the first when McCutchen doubled with two outs then scored on a single by Jones.	It would be all the cushion the Pirates needed while Samardzija lost a 1-0 decision for the second time in a month.	You take it with a grain of salt
column15: said Samardzija, who walked one and struck out eight. That's just the way the game goes sometimes. You give up five runs and get a win sometimes."	Or
column16: in the case of the Pirates
column17: whenever Liriano is on the mound.	The Pirates agreed to terms with the former All-Star in December
column18: but Liriano signed a more incentive-laden deal after breaking his right (non-throwing) arm in a freak accident on Christmas Day.	It's certainly looking like a bargain now. The left-hander has spent most of the five seasons attempting to regain the form he showed as a 22-year-old phenom with the Minnesota Twins in 2006
column19: when he went 12-3 with a 2.16 ERA and made the All-Star team on his way to finishing third in American League Rookie of the Year voting.	His path to stardom was sidetracked by Tommy John surgery in 2007
column20: though he appears to have found a home in Pittsburgh.	Mixing his offspeed stuff with a rejuvenated fastball refined by a tweak to his delivery
column21: Liriano has joined A.J. Burnett and Wandy Rodriguez in giving the Pirates a respectable top of the rotation.	"I think I work hard in the offseason
column22: location-wise with my fastball and everything is working so far
column23: Liriano said. Pitching is all about location so when you can locate your pitches
column24: you have better results."	He was solid in his first two starts in wins over the Mets and Milwaukee. He was spectacular at times against the Cubs. He retired 14 of 15 batters at one point and managed to expertly wiggle out of the lone spot of trouble in the third when the Cubs loaded the bases with no outs following a Cody Ransom single
column25: a walk and an error.	In a way
column26: Liriano had the Cubs right where he wanted them.	Chicago began the night hitting just .218 with runners in scoring position
column27: the second-lowest in the majors.	The number dropped a bit more after Julio Borbon hit into a fielders' choice
column28: Starlin Castro struck out and Anthony Rizzo flew out to right to end the threat.	No Cub made it to third base over Liriano's final four innings and Pittsburgh's bullpen made it hold up. The Pirates are 21-1 when leading after seven innings this season.	Tony Watson worked the eighth and the Cubs made Melancon work in the ninth.	Alfonso Soriano reached on strikeout-wild pitch and Wellington Castillo singled with one out. Nate Schierholtz and Darwin Barney both lofted weak fly balls to shallow right field that Pittsburgh second baseman Neil Walker corralled with ease.	Game notes	Chicago's Darwin Barney
column29: who went 4 for 4 in the series opener on Tuesday to raise his average from .192 to .223
column30: went 0 for 3 ... Pittsburgh's left-handed starters are 8-1 at PNC Park this season ... The series wraps up on Thursday. Jeanmar Gomez (2-0
column31: 2.78 ERA) will make his first start against the Cubs. Edwin Jackson (1-6 5.76) starts for Chicago. Jackson is 4-1 with a 3.09 ERA against the Pirates in his career.	Detroit got a jump-start on the winter signings
column32: landing lefty Eduardo Rodriguez. We break down the deal.	In a free-agent field filled with future Hall of Famers
column33: Detroit added one of the most undervalued pitchers available this winter.	Joon Lee breaks down how Eduardo Rodriguez signing with Detroit affects the Tigers and Red Sox.	Check out some of the most electric moments from Vladimir Guerrero Jr.'s career.	Former Boston Red Sox left-hander Eduardo Rodriguez and the Detroit Tigers are in agreement on a five-year deal worth $77 million
column34: sources confirmed to ESPN.	From who we think deserves MVP and Cy Young to if the voters got it right
column35: this is your one-stop shop as baseball's 2021 hardware is handed out.

column1: MIAMI -- Once Cliff Lee escaped an early jam
column2: the rest seemed to come easily.	Lee pitched a three-hitter for his 12th career shutout and Delmon Young homered for the second straight game
column3: sending the Philadelphia Phillies past the Miami Marlins 3-0 on Wednesday night.	Lee (5-2) struck out five
column4: walked two and hit a batter in his first shutout since Sept. 5
column5: 2011.	"I know I got lucky early in the game with the bases loaded and nobody out
column7: Lee said. I felt like I got better as the game went on
column8: too."	The Marlins failed to score despite that threat in the second inning. Nick Green grounded into a third-to-home-to-first double play and Jeff Mathis popped up.	"I was willing to sacrifice a run right there for two outs
column10: he hit it to third base where we could get the guy at home and then throw to first
column11: so that was huge."	Lee has allowed three or less runs in eight of his 10 starts. Miami's only hits were Marcell Ozuna's infield single leading off the second
column12: Miguel Olivo's lined single opening the sixth and Derek Dietrich's infield single in the ninth.	The Marlins were blanked for the ninth time this season.	"We had that one opportunity to score and didn't get it done and that was about it
column13: Miami manager Mike Redmond said.	Lee also got two hits.	It's the funnest part of the game for me
column14: he said. Anytime I can do anything to help the team win
column15: I try to take it serious."	Young hit a solo home run off Kevin Slowey (1-5) in the fourth. It was Young's third homer
column16: including a drive off Miami's Jose Fernandez on Tuesday night.	"I feel like I'm ready in time and I'm able to recognize the pitch early
column17:
Young said.	Slowey exited before the sixth inning with a strained left lat muscle. The Marlins said he was day to day.	Slowey allowed six hits and struck out six.	Philadelphia scored twice off Wade LeBlanc with two outs in the sixth to go ahead 3-0.	Young reached on a two-out infield hit and scored on Domonic Brown's triple. Freddy Galvis singled home Brown.	In the fifth, Chris Coghlan walked but was thrown out at second as he tried to advance when Green flied out to deep right. Young threw to shortstop Jimmy Rollins, who applied the tag as Coghlan slid in headfirst.	Game notes	After the game, the Phillies announced RHP Phillippe Aumont was being sent to Triple-A Lehigh Valley. Philadelphia will add a player on Friday to take Aumont's spot. ... Philadelphia 2B Chase Utley is scheduled for an MRI on Thursday on his sore	ribcage. He was scratched from the lineup for Philadelphia's 7-3 win on Tuesday night after feeling discomfort during batting practice. ... Miami RF Giancarlo Stanton (strained hamstring) took swings on the field during batting practice for the first time since going on the disabled list April 30. He hopes to begin running next week. ... The Phillies (23-24) have not been at .500 since being 6-6 on April 14.	The Braves added depth at catcher by signing Manny Pina to a two-year, $8 million contract.	Randy Arozarena celebrates with his family at home after learning he won the 2021 AL Rookie of the Year.	From MVP to Cy Young and more, this is your one-stop shop as baseball's 2021 hardware is handed out.	Randy Arozarena hit 20 home runs and stole 20 bases this season, leading all rookies with a 4.1 WAR.	Take a look back at the best plays from NL Rookie of the Year Jonathan India's 2021 campaign.	Julio Lugo, who played for seven teams in a 12-year major league career, has died. He was 45.

Red Sox 6, White Sox 2.
CHICAGO -- Clay Buchholz figures a slump will come his way at some point so he'll enjoy this run while it lasts.	Buchholz pitched five-hit ball over seven innings to improve to 7-0, and the Boston Red Sox beat the Chicago White Sox 6-2 Wednesday night to avoid a three-game sweep.	David Ortiz delivered a two-run single in the first off Hector Santiago (1-3) and stole third for the first time in his career. Jacoby Ellsbury had two hits, walked twice and made a big catch in center field to back Buchholz and help the Red Sox come away with their sixth win in eight games.	They're now 9-1 with Buchholz starting, and he has gone at least six innings each time out.	You're going to take your lumps and bumps in the road
column18: he said.	But it has been a smooth ride so far for him, although he got some help from his defense in this one.	Jonny Gomes made a sliding catch on Paul Konerko's line drive to left with two on to end the first, and Ellsbury raced to the center-field warning track to snag Alexei Ramirez's liner with a runner on and two out in the fifth to preserve a 2-1 lead.	Boston added to it in the eighth when Will Middlebrooks hit a sacrifice fly to right off Nate Jones after the Red Sox loaded the bases against Brian Omogrosso in the eighth, and Mike Napoli scored on a passed ball by Tyler Flowers to make it 4-1. The Red Sox scored two more in the ninth to put this one away.	Even so, Konerko was feeling pretty good about how the White Sox played in this series.	It's good for our record
column19: but I think it should be good for our confidence that we belong on the same field as some of these teams
column20: he said. I don't think we doubt that anyway
column21: but it reinforces it."	Buchholz allowed just one run while lowering his American League-leading ERA to 1.73. He also matched the best start by a Boston pitcher since Josh Beckett in 2007 and joined Tampa Bay's Matt Moore and Arizona's Patrick Corbin as the only unbeaten pitchers in the majors with seven or more wins.	"I thought tonight
column24: Red Sox manager John Farrell said. He's still pitching in the low to mid-90s with his fastball. The biggest thing is you never can sit on any one pitch in any given count."	The only run Buchholz allowed came on an RBI groundout in the third by Alex Rios
column25: who extended his career-high hitting streak to 17 with a single in the sixth.	The White Sox also got a solo homer from Konerko off Andrew Bailey. Otherwise
column26: the White Sox couldn't get the big hit. They were 0-for-5 with runners in scoring position after doing all their scoring with two outs while winning the previous two games 6-4 and 3-1.	Santiago wasn't quite as dominant after Jose Quintana took a no-hitter into the seventh the previous night
column27: but he gave the White Sox exactly what they needed.	He settled down after the shaky start and threw six solid innings for the White Sox with Chris Sale scratched because of mild tendinitis in his left shoulder. The left-hander allowed two runs and three hits
column28: struck out nine and walked four pitching on three days' rest in what might be his last start for a while.	That's because he or Dylan Axelrod could be headed to the bullpen with John Danks expected to return from his shoulder injury.	"It's tough
column29: but that's part of being in baseball
column30: White Sox manager Robin Ventura said. We have to figure out what's best for us
column31: so we'll figure that out on Friday."	Game notes	Ortiz was having some fun after the game in light of his steal of third in the first inning. Asked if he's the new Rickey Henderson
column33: "So they say." And when he saw the steal sign
column36: 'You sure?'" ... The Red Sox held OF Shane Victorino out of the lineup for the second straight game because of tightness in his left hamstring. Manager John Farrell said there has been improvement and is hopeful he won't have to go on the disabled list. ... Farrell said backup C David Ross (concussion) will go on a rehab assignment Thursday at Double-A Portland. ... The White Sox said after the game that Danks will be activated from the disabled list and make his first start of the year against Miami on Friday. Danks is coming off a season-ending shoulder injury and his not pitched since May 19
column37: 2012. He had surgery in August to repair a capsule tear and remove debris in his rotator cuff and biceps. To make room for Danks
column38: the White Sox optioned left-hander Donnie Veal to Triple-A Charlotte after Wednesday's game.	Detroit got a jump-start on the winter signings
column39: landing lefty Eduardo Rodriguez. We break down the deal.	In a free-agent field filled with future Hall of Famers
column40: Detroit added one of the most undervalued pitchers available this winter.	Joon Lee breaks down how Eduardo Rodriguez signing with Detroit affects the Tigers and Red Sox.	Check out some of the most electric moments from Vladimir Guerrero Jr.'s career.	Former Boston Red Sox left-hander Eduardo Rodriguez and the Detroit Tigers are in agreement on a five-year deal worth $77 million

column1: HOUSTON -- The Houston Astros got another good outing from their starting pitcher
column2: and their bullpen was just fine for a change.	J.D. Martinez hit a two-run homer off James Shields
column3: Jordan Lyles pitched six effective innings and the Astros beat the Kansas City Royals 3-1 on Wednesday night.	Lyles (2-1) allowed one run and six hits in his 50th career game. Travis Blackley and Hector Ambriz each got three outs before Jose Veras pitched a perfect ninth for his eighth save one night after the bullpen struggled in a 7-3 loss.	"They've been taxed a lot this year and called upon on numerous occasions
column4: so every once in a while you're going to have the kind of game that we had last night
column5: manager Bo Porter said. But again
column6: it speaks to the character of the men down there. They hold themselves accountable to holding a lead
column7: and tonight they did a tremendous job. All of them."	Bud Norris pitched six shutout innings Tuesday
column8: but the Royals scored seven times in the final three innings. Houston bounced back quite nicely to take two of three for its fourth series win this season.	Shields (2-5) struck out seven in seven innings while yielding two runs and seven hits. He has gone seven or more innings in each of his last six starts
column9: but hasn't won since April 30 due in part to his offense providing him with just five runs combined in his last four starts.	"It's a little frustrating
column10: manager Ned Yost said. Especially when James Shields goes out and gives you the type of performance he gives you about every time he goes out. We just have not done a good job with run support with him at all."	Shields is confident it will turn around soon.	"These guys are great. They are grinding every day
column11: Shields said. We are going through a little struggle right now. Our heads are high

column13: who was acquired in an offseason trade with Tampa Bay

column15: first inning which is huge and it gives Lyles a little bit of comfort as well
column16: Martinez said. Pitchers like that ... good guys

column1: SAN DIEGO -- Tyler Lyons scrolled through his phone
column2: scanning all the text messages congratulating the left-hander on his winning major league debut. His teammates were quite appreciative
column3: too.	Lyons pitched seven solid innings on the same day St. Louis lost Jaime Garcia for the season
column4: and the Cardinals beat the San Diego Padres 5-3 on Wednesday night.	"It was everything I could ask for
column5: said Lyons, who also got his first major league hit on a single in the sixth. I pitched well
column6: I got a hit and we won the ballgame. It doesn't get much better than that."	Lyons
column7: who was promoted from Triple-A Memphis after Garcia went on the disabled list
column8: used an effective sinker to limit the Padres to one run and four hits. The 25-year-old Lyons was a ninth-round draft pick in 2010 out of Oklahoma State.	The Cardinals announced before that game that Garcia will have season-ending shoulder surgery this week. The lefty went 5-2 with a 3.58 ERA in nine starts this year
column9: helping St. Louis bolt to the majors' best record at 30-16.	Yadier Molina had four hits and Carlos Beltran finished with three as the Cardinals took two of three from the Padres.	Lyons continued a positive trend this season for St. Louis
column10: which has used six rookie starting pitchers already. Lyons is the second lefty to get a win in his major league debut in the last nine days. The other is John Gast
column11: who beat the New York Mets on May 14.	"It's been of great benefit to get solid outings out of some young pitchers
column12: manager Mike Matheny said. These guys have come into some tough situations and performed admirably.	"We're proud of how the guys are going about their business despite instances that could be described as adversity. They play hard every day and they put a lot of faith in each other and the next man up."	While Lyons pitched well
column13: San Diego rookie Burch Smith failed to record an out in the second inning for the second time in three major league starts. He was optioned to Triple-A Tucson after the game.	The right-hander struggled with his command
column14: walking three before he was lifted with no outs in the second. Tim Stauffer came in and got Matt Holliday to hit into a double play
column15: but Matt Carpenter scored to give the Cardinals a 4-0 lead.	Smith allowed five hits and has given up 15 runs and 16 hits in just 7 1/3 innings. The Padres will make a corresponding roster move on Friday at Arizona.	"Burch has excellent stuff
column16: but at times it looked as though he was trying too hard
column17: manager Bud Black said. He struggled against major league hitters but
column18: in the long run
column19: this guy's going to be fine."	Holliday had an RBI triple in the first that was confirmed by a video review. The ball landed just below the yellow border in right field
column20: but it came down from a difficult angle that prompted Matheny to question whether it was a home run.	Holliday scored on Allen Craig's single
column21: and Daniel Descalso added a run-scoring double.	Molina singled in a run in the fifth but that was the only blemish for Stauffer
column22: who allowed eight hits and struck out seven in 5 2/3 innings.	Stauffer kept San Diego in the game
column23: but the offense never got going.	Rookie Jedd Gyorko got the Padres on the board with a towering home run to center field in the seventh. Gyorko's drive went 438 feet and is the longest at Petco Park this season. He has the three longest Padres home runs this season.	Alexi Amarista added a two-run single in the ninth for San Diego. column1: PITTSBURGH --  It was hard to tell whether the Pittsburgh Pirates were heading on a road trip or getting ready for a Stanley Cup playoff game after beating the Chicago Cubs 4-2 on Thursday for their fourth straight win.	All of the Pirates' players and coaches wore Pittsburgh Penguins' replica jerseys as they got ready to embark on a road trip to Milwaukee and Detroit. The Penguins even sent a custom-made No. 13 sweater to manager Clint Hurdle.	The Penguins lead the Ottawa Senators 3-1 in their best-of-seven Eastern Conference semifinal.	"There's nothing much like playoff hockey
column2: Hurdle said. We're just getting into the spirit."	Utility infielder Brandon Inge took things one step farther before the game
column3: arriving in the Pirates' clubhouse dressed in a full hockey uniform and rollerblades.	"It's something fun
column4: something to change things up a little bit during a long season. Plus
column5: we've got to support our boys
column6: said Pirates second baseman Neil Walker, a Pittsburgh-area native.	The Pirates won for the 11th time in 13 games as Andrew McCutchen had three hits and two RBIs.	Leadoff hitter Starling Marte singled and scored in each of the first two innings as Pittsburgh built an early 4-0 lead. The Pirates moved a season-best 11 games over .500.	We're playing good baseball and I don't think we've reached our ceiling yet
column7: McCutchen said. The pitching has been good all year but the hitting has kind of been up and down. The bats are eventually going to come around and we should be even better when that happens."	The Cubs lost their fourth in a row.	Edwin Jackson (1-7) gave up two runs in the first inning and two more in the second. He gave up six hits and struck out six in three innings and has a 6.11 ERA through 10 starts.	"I got beat with men on base with balls up in the zone
column8: Jackson said. I had some times when I got it down but in vital situations when I needed to keep the ball down I wasn't doing that

column1: TORONTO -- With his first major league start in the books
column2: Kevin Gausman was looking forward to a good night's rest.	Edwin Encarnacion hit his fifth career grand slam
column3: J.P. Arencibia homered and drove in four runs and the Toronto Blue Jays beat Baltimore 12-6 on Thursday night
column4: spoiling Gausman's Orioles debut.	"Definitely a learning experience for me but it was awesome
column5: Gausman said. It was everything I could have imagined and more.	"I've been waiting my entire life for this. I haven't been able to sleep very much lately. That was something that was kind of great to get out of the way. Hopefully
column6: I can sleep tonight."	The fourth overall pick in the 2012 draft
column7: Gausman allowed four runs and seven hits in five innings. The right-hander walked two and struck out five.	"He gave us a chance to win against a team swinging the bat as hot as anybody
column8: Orioles manager Buck Showalter said. I thought he handled himself the way you'd like to see a young pitcher handle himself. He's only going to get better."	The youngest starter in the AL at 22 years and 137 days
column9: Gausman showed some veteran composure in the third
column10: loading the bases with none out before retiring the next three batters.	"His changeup was a big pitch for him tonight and he was able to use it in some key situations
column11: catcher Matt Wieters said. The slider was there if we needed it
column12: too.	"That's a good hitting team and a good hitting fastball team and he was able to make some balls miss some barrels
column13: Wieters added.	Even Blue Jays manager John Gibbons was impressed.	He's got a great arm
column14: Gibbons said. He pitched with good composure. He looks like he belongs out there. For a debut he did a heck of a job."	Promoted from Double-A Bowie to face Toronto
column15: Gausman learned that big league hitters are a cut above the opponents he's been facing.	"I threw a great changeup 3-2 to (Colby) Rasmus and he just kind of spit on it
column16: Gausman said. At this level
column17: those guys are so good it's kind of crazy."	Gausman (0-1) is the 11th pitcher to start for Baltimore this year. The Orioles used 12 starters all of last season.	Baltimore's Chris Davis hit his major league leading 15th home run
column18: a leadoff shot in the fourth. Nick Markakis and Adam Jones hit back-to-back homers off Brandon Morrow to start the eighth but it wasn't enough for the Orioles
column19: who lost for the seventh time in nine games.	Baltimore's Manny Machado went 3-for-4 with three doubles
column20: boosting his major league-leading total to 21.	Morrow (2-3) allowed six runs and a season-high 10 hits in seven-plus innings. He walked one and struck out five.	"It's frustrating for me to go out give up the two home runs without getting an out there in the eighth
column21: Morrow said. It's a good win
column22: but it put a sour taste in my mouth."	Brett Cecil and Brad Lincoln each worked one inning of scoreless relief as Toronto won for the third time in four games.	Machado gave the Orioles an early lead with a two-run double in the third. Davis made it 3-0 by homering on Morrow's first pitch of the fourth
column23: but the Blue Jays rallied with two runs off Gausman in the bottom half. Adam Lind and Arencibia led off with consecutive doubles and Emilio Bonifacio hit a sacrifice fly.	Arencibia put the Blue Jays in front with a two-out
column24: first-pitch drive in the fifth for his 11th homer.	Troy Patton was replaced after issuing back-to-back two-out walks in the sixth. Pedro Strop came on and walked Jose Bautista before Encarnacion homered off the left field foul screen
column25: Toronto's first grand slam this season.	Five of the eight walks issued by Baltimore pitchers came around to score.	"You like your chances when you score six but not when you walk that many people
column26: Showalter said.	After Alexi Casilla hit a sacrifice fly in the seventh, Markakis hit his fifth home run in the eighth and Jones followed with his seventh. It's the third time this season the Orioles have hit consecutive homers.	Toronto put it away with four runs off T.J. McFarland in a bat-around eighth. Anthony Gose scored from second on a passed ball after Wieters threw to second, Arencibia hit an RBI grounder, Brett Lawrie singled home a run and Rasmus hit a sacrifice fly.	Left fielder Nate McLouth tumbled into the stands after running into the wall in foul territory while retiring Rasmus for the first out of the sixth. Fans tried to indicate that McLouth had dropped the ball, but third base umpire Manny Gonzalez ruled it an out. After the play, a fan in the second deck threw a drink at McLouth, bringing Showalter out for a discussion with the umpires.	Both Showalter and McLouth downplayed the incident.	It just kind of startled me for a second
column27: McLouth said. I'm not really sure how close it landed. That's just one person doing something they shouldn't do."	Game notes	The Blue Jays are 15-0 when scoring five runs or more. ... Jones
column28: who has been bothered by a sore groin
column29: made his third straight start at DH. RHP Chad Jenkins will start Sunday. ... To clear a roster spot for Gausman
column30: the Orioles optioned RHP Jake Arrieta to Triple-A Norfolk and designated RHP Alex Burnett for assignment. ... A moment of silence was held before the game in memory of scout Epy Guerrero
column31: who died Thursday at 71. ... Former Blue Jays infielder Homer Bush threw out the first pitch. ... Showalter celebrated his 57th birthday. column1: DETROIT -- Jim Leyland is usually pretty confident about his managerial moves.	Thursday
column3: he wasn't entirely sure if he had done something smart or stupid.	With the game tied in the eighth

column5: and Leyland decided to have Torii Hunter bunt him to second.	That put the go-ahead run in scoring position
column6: but meant taking the bat out of the hands of Miguel Cabrera
column7: baseball's hottest hitter.	"That was a tough call
column8: Leyland acknowledged after the game. That's definitely a move that the fans are going to discuss
column9: and I don't have any problem with that. I wasn't sure

column12: and facing right-hander Jared Burton.	"If they had a tough lefty to pitch to Prince -- maybe Glen Perkins if it had been the ninth inning -- I might not have bunted
column13: Leyland said. Prince has 40 RBIs hitting behind Miguel Cabrera
column14: so I was willing to roll the dice with him."	The plan worked
column15: but only barely. Fielder hit what looked like a possible double-play grounder
column16: but it deflected off Burton's glove and past second baseman Brian Dozier. Infante scored easily
column17: and the Tigers held on to win 7-6.	"You hate walking anyone to pitch to Prince Fielder
column18: I can tell you that right now

column27: Tigers starter Rick Porcello said. If I were pitching against them

column30: but scored three times off three Minnesota pitchers. Infante singled and Cabrera walked with one out
column31: bringing Brian Duensing into the game. He allowed RBI singles to Prince Fielder and Victor Martinez before giving way to Burton.	Jhonny Peralta greeted Burton (0-2) with a game-tying double

column1: BOSTON -- Terry Francona returned to Fenway Park and found some more pleasant memories.	A standing ovation. A video tribute to his time as manager of the Boston Red Sox. And
column3: a win for his Cleveland Indians.	Drew Stubbs
column4: Mark Reynolds and Michael Bourn combined for nine hits and eight RBIs and the Indians had 16 hits in their 12-3 win on Thursday night.	"I tried to keep my emotions inside
column5: said Francona, who led the Red Sox to two World Series championships in eight years. I didn't want to be the main focus. You want to let the players play."	Francona
column6: let go by Boston after the 2011 season
column7: got the ovation after the first inning during a video display on the center-field scoreboard. He raised his left hand to the crowd and tapped his heart with his right.	"I was honored
column8: he said.	And, perhaps, just a bit emotional.	It was just neat to see the organization do that for him
column9: Reynolds said. I think I saw him teary-eyed a little bit during that thing. It was pretty neat and I was glad to be a part of it."	It was the fans' only chance to cheer for Francona. He didn't bring out the lineup card and didn't have to leave the visiting dugout during the game because all of Cleveland's pitching changes came at the start of an inning.	He had left Boston as the second winningest manager
column11: in club history.	In his first year as Cleveland's manager
column12: he has the Indians in first place in the AL Central after they went 68-94 last season.	They're 22-9 in their last 31 games.	"They've got a good team and are in first place for a reason
column14: said Boston manager John Farrell, Francona's former pitching coach with the Red Sox.	The 12 runs are the most scored by the Indians in the park since June 28, 2005 and the most they scored there without a home run since 1953.	Homers (have) been known to be rally killers
column15: Reynolds said. You keep having guys on base
column16: it keeps the pressure on the pitcher and it makes him be precise."	Zach McAllister (4-3) allowed three runs in five innings. He hasn't allowed more than three earned runs in any of his nine starts this year. Scott Barnes earned his first major-league save by pitching three shutout innings.	"I think everyone wanted to go out there and get a win
column17: not just for the team but for (Francona) also
column18: McAllister said. He's been great for us this year and he's well liked everywhere he is. It's definitely exciting to get him a win."	Ryan Dempster (2-5) gave up four runs in three innings with four walks in his third straight poor start for Boston.	"My command has been terrible
column19: he said. I have walked 10 guys in the last nine innings. Bottom line is I've got to fix that. I can't get myself in that kind of trouble."	Every Cleveland starting batter had a hit and all except Jason Kipnis scored. Carlos Santana reached base five times with a single and four walks.	The Indians took a 1-0 lead in the first on an RBI double by Stubbs and made it 4-0 in the third
column20: scoring on a two-run single by Reynolds and a force play at second on a grounder by Mike Aviles.	The Red Sox cut that to 4-3 in the third on David Ortiz's eighth homer of the season but wasted a chance for a bigger inning. Jacoby Ellsbury led off with a single and took second on a walk to Daniel Nava. Dustin Pedroia then singled
column21: but Ellsbury was thrown out at the plate by center fielder Bourn. Ortiz then hit the next pitch for his three-run homer.	Run-scoring singles by Asdrubal Cabrera in the fourth and Bourn in the fifth made it 6-3 before the Indians scored six runs when they sent 10 men to the plate in the sixth.	They loaded the bases with no outs on a walk to Cabrera
column22: a single by Michael Brantley and a walk to Santana. Alex Wilson replaced Clayton Mortensen and gave up an RBI single to Reynolds. Yan Gomes followed with a two-run double after first baseman Mike Napoli dropped his foul pop for an error.	Aviles hit an infield pop for the first out
column23: but Stubbs tripled in two runs and Bourn singled in another before Wilson struck out the next two batters.	That was more than enough for Francona to relax the rest of the way with a big lead.	"He's one of the best managers to ever manage here
column24: Boston catcher Jarrod Saltalamacchia said. I wasn't surprised by the (fans') reaction. It is all earned and deserved."	Game notes	Dempster had his shortest start of the season
column25: lasting three innings. His previous shortest came in his prior start

column2: Mo. -- Joe Blanton got some backing from the Angels' bats and bullpen
column3: and finally got his first win of the season.	Mike Trout and Albert Pujols hit solo home runs
column4: and Mark Trumbo hit a two-run shot to help Los Angeles beat the Kansas City Royals 5-4 on Thursday night.	With Jered Weaver set to return to the Angels' rotation
column5: Blanton could have been feeling pressure after going winless in his first nine starts.	"I've been doing it a long time. Why should I feel a sense of urgency now?" Blanton said.	The right-hander held the Royals to seven hits and two runs in 6 1/3 innings. Trumbo put the Angels up 5-2 in the eighth with his team-leading 11th homer before the Royals made it interesting.	"I thought we showed a lot of life at the end of the game

column1: WASHINGTON --  The Washington Nationals didn't have a close shave
column2: and neither did Davey Johnson.	The 70-year-old manager still looked closer to 80 after the Nationals beat the Philadelphia Phillies 5-2 Friday night
column3: sporting the scraggly beginnings of facial hair he had vowed to keep until his team started hitting.	Five runs weren't enough
column4: even though it was the most the Nationals had scored in a week. There was also a four-run fifth
column5: the first time Washington had put up four or more in an inning in almost a month.	Johnson said he told a couple of his players: "It's getting close to coming off."	Their response: "They said it can't come off yet
column7: she probably wants me to take it off
column9: Johnson said. But I might leave it on
column10: see if this is not something strange happening here."	The outburst of hitting provided the rare gift of a cushion for Jordan Zimmermann
column11: who became the National League's first eight-game winner as Washington followed a calamitous road trip with a winning start to a homestand.	Zimmermann (8-2)
column12: pitching with a stiff neck that limited his control of his fastball
column13: allowed two runs and six hits with no walks over seven innings -- actually raising his ERA to 1.71 -- on an unseasonably chilly and windy night in the nation's capital.	"I kind of cut him a little shorter than I normally would
column14: Johnson said. He still threw a heck of a ball game."	There was at least a bit of heat from the Nationals' lineup
column16: second worst in the majors. Washington had just completed a 10-game West Coast road trip that included a four-game losing streak
column17: the team's sixth shutout loss of the season
column18: Bryce Harper's head-first collision with a wall and a broken hand for Ryan Mattheus after he punched his locker following a rough outing.	Then Johnson arrived at the ballpark Friday saying: "I decided I wouldn't shave until we started hitting."	If Johnson does pull out the razor
column19: Steve Lombardozzi should get due credit. Playing second while Danny Espinosa recovers from a broken wrist
column22: two-run double that capped the rally in the four-run fifth.	"We score on pass balls
column24: Johnson said. We haven't been getting base hits. To score five runs
column25: we've been kind of stuck on none or one or two
column26: so that was a big shot in the arm."	Phillies starter Kyle Kendrick (4-3) had his shortest outing of the season
column27: allowing five runs and eight hits over five innings. He walked four for the second consecutive start
column28: including three consecutive bases on balls that allowed the Nationals to score a run in the second with a sacrifice fly and no hits.	"Command was bad
column29: threw a lot of balls
column30: didn't get ahead in the count
column31: Kendrick said. Another one of those nights where it was 2-0
column33: and I threw a lot of pitches."	The Phillies missed a chance to pull even in two ways. A win would have put them at .500 for the first time since April 14
column34: and it also would have tied them with the Nationals
column35: who had lost four of five and have been mired in mediocrity while dealing with the expectations of Johnson's preseason proclamation of "World Series or bust."	"Obviously
column36: we've kind of been up and down all year
column37: Kendrick said. We had a chance to get it back tonight. Had a couple runs there and I couldn't hold it."	Game notes	Rafael Soriano picked up his 14th save. ... Washington's last four-run inning came April 25 against the Cincinnati Reds. ... Headgear on both players when flying when Tyler Moore crashed into Kratz while trying to score on Lombardozzi's single in the fourth inning. Kratz held on to the ball
column38: and Moore was out. ... Both teams are missing star power. The Phillies don't have Roy Halladay (shoulder surgery) and Chase Utley (oblique strain)
column39: while the Nationals are making do without Jayson Werth (hamstring) and Espinosa
column40: who learned Friday that he's been playing with a slight fracture in his right wrist and will need a few days of rest
column41: if not more. ... The Nationals plan to bring up INF-OF Jeff Kobernus from Triple-A Syracuse on Saturday and will likely designate RHP Yunesky Maya for assignment. ... Philadelphia recalled INF-OF Michael Martinez and RHP Michael Stutes to replace Utley (disabled list) and RHP Phillippe Aumont (optioned to Triple-A Lehigh Valley). ... Phillies RHP Mike Adams (right back strain) felt fine after a second rehab bullpen session Friday and is expected to be reactivated Sunday. ... Washington LHP Ross Detwiler will throw a full bullpen session Saturday and remains on pace to return to the rotation Tuesday after skipping one start because of back spasms.	Jonathan India finished ahead of Cardinals OF Dylan Carlson and Marlins starter Trevor Rogers for NL Rookie of the Year.	The Yankees hired former Mets manager Luis Rojas as their new third-base coach on Monday.	Detroit got a jump-start on the winter signings
column42: landing lefty Eduardo Rodriguez. We break down the deal.	In a free-agent field filled with future Hall of Famers
column43: Detroit added one of the most undervalued pitchers available this winter.	Joon Lee breaks down how Eduardo Rodriguez signing with Detroit affects the Tigers and Red Sox.	Check out some of the most electric moments from Vladimir Guerrero Jr.'s career.

column1: TORONTO -- The Baltimore Orioles are bashing home runs at an impressive rate right now.	Chris Davis hit his major league-leading 16th homer and Baltimore beat the Toronto Blue Jays 10-6 on Friday night.	J.J. Hardy
column2: Danny Valencia and Adam Jones also went deep as the Orioles matched a season high in runs and set a season high with four home runs. Baltimore has hit an ML-best 66 homers this season.	"When we got a ball over the plate it seemed like we didn't miss it
column3: said Baltimore's Nick Markakis, who had three hits and three RBIs.	The Orioles have hit at least three homers in each of the past four games, their first such streak since a five-game run in August 1996.	That year, the Orioles finished with eight double-digit home run hitters and set a baseball record with 257 homers.	While this Baltimore squad might not be on pace to match those lofty marks, there's still plenty of power.	They didn't miss anything
column4: Toronto manager John Gibbons said.	The teams combined for 33 hits, 16 by Baltimore and 17 by Toronto.	It was pinball out there tonight
column5: Gibbons said.	Chris Tillman (4-2) allowed three runs and a season-high 10 hits in five innings to win for the fourth time in six starts. He walked none and matched a season high with seven strikeouts.	The key was Tillman not walking anybody
column6: said Baltimore manager Buck Showalter. You've got to make them earn it."	The Orioles walked eight batters in Thursday's 12-6 loss.	Brian Matusz got two outs in the sixth
column7: Tommy Hunter pitched 2 1/3 innings and Darren O'Day finished in the ninth.	Toronto lost for the first time this season when scoring five runs or more
column8: falling to 15-1 in those games. The Blue Jays set a dubious franchise record by allowing the first three batters of an inning to reach safely in three consecutive frames
column10: second and third.	Toronto catcher J.P. Arencibia was the only starter on either side who didn't reach safely via a hit or walk. He went 0 for 5 with three strikeouts.	Melky Cabrera
column11: Brett Lawrie and Adam Lind all hit solo homers for the Blue Jays
column12: but Lawrie and Gibbons were ejected at the end of the third.	Blue Jays left-hander Sean Nolin was hit hard in his major league debut
column13: allowing six runs and seven hits in 1 1/3 innings. Called up from Double-A to face the Orioles
column14: Nolin (0-1) suffered his first loss since Aug. 27
column16: when he was pitching for Class A Lansing.	"Definitely not the way I envisioned it
column17: a red-eyed Nolin said. I think I just had too much energy going. I kind of felt like I already threw a few innings
column18: kind of wasted some gas without doing anything."	Gibbons agreed that Nolin didn't seem to have his best stuff.	"It was a tough go for him
column19: no question
column20: Gibbons said. Arencibia told me everything was kind of flat
column21: flat in the zone."	Optioned back to the minors after the game
column22: Nolin put his team in a hole before recording his first out. After singles by Markakis and Manny Machado
column23: Hardy hit a three-run drive to left
column24: his ninth.	Cabrera got one run back with his first career leadoff homer and second of the season in the bottom half
column25: but the Orioles chased Nolin with three more in the third. A double
column26: a walk and a single loaded the bases for Markakis
column27: who cleared them with a double.	Lawrie led off the bottom of the second with his fifth home run and Colby Rasmus doubled and scored on Emilio Bonifacio's single
column28: but the Orioles added to their lead in the fourth against Ramon Ortiz.	Davis led off with a second deck homer
column29: his third in three games and fourth in five. Two batters later
column30: Valencia hit his first homer
column31: a two-run drive.	Jones made it 10-3 with a leadoff homer off Brad Lincoln in the sixth
column32: but the Blue Jays scored twice against Matusz in the bottom half. Munenori Kawasaki hit an RBI double and scored on Cabrera's single.	Lind cut it to 10-6 with an opposite field homer off Hunter in the seventh
column33: his fourth.	Lawrie was ejected by home plate umpire Dan Bellino after he was called out looking to strand runners at the corners in the third. Lawrie flipped his bat and tossed his helmet and gloves on the ground as he walked up the third base line toward his position
column34: leading to his first ejection this season.	"I didn't do anything
column35: Lawrie said. I didn't say one word to him
column37: I didn't look at him one time and I'm in trouble for that."	Bellino warned Lawrie about an equipment violation before the ejection
column38: but Lawrie said he didn't hear it over the noise of the crowd. Crew chief Wally Bell said Lawrie was ejected because for throwing his gloves "in a way that wasn't etiquette in baseball."	Gibbons was tossed for the third time when he came out to argue.	"Next time he's got to throw his gloves in the other direction
column40:
Gibbons said.	Game notes	For Machado, it was his fifth straight road game with at least three hits. He's just the second player younger than 21 to do so, joining Hall of Famer Ty Cobb, who did it in 1907, according to information from the Elias Sports Bureau. ... Mark DeRosa replaced Lawrie. ... Orioles pitching prospect Dylan Bundy, who was shut down last month because of elbow pain, reported full range of motion and no pain in his arm during an examination Friday. Bundy is not yet ready to resume throwing. ... Baltimore's Jones returned to the outfield after three straight starts at DH. ... To make room on the roster for Nolin, the Blue Jays placed LHP Darren Oliver (shoulder) on the 15-day DL and moved LHP J.A. Happ (head, knee) from the 15-day DL to the 60-day DL. ... Toronto will make another move Saturday to replace Nolin.	The Braves added depth at catcher by signing Manny Pina to a two-year, $8 million contract. DETROIT -- Add another near miss in this 2013 baseball season -- this time it was Detroit's Anibal Sanchez falling just short of a no-hitter.	Sanchez's bid was broken up with one out in the ninth inning Friday night when Minnesota's Joe Mauer hit a clean single up the middle. That was the only hit the right-hander allowed in the Tigers' 6-0 victory against the Twins. It was the fourth one-hitter of Sanchez's career, to go along with a no-hitter he threw as a rookie back in 2006.	It's not that I go to the mound and want to do something special; it's just that I want to go nine innings
column41: go deeper
column42: get a good command
column43: get a good game
column44: Sanchez said. When I come to the eighth inning
column45: I think about it. But when I come to the ninth inning
column46: it's really tough with those guys."	After seven no-hitters in 2012
column47: baseball is without one so far this season. There have been plenty of close calls. Before Sanchez
column48: four other pitchers already had thrown one-hitters in 2013
column49: according to STATS. And that doesn't include Yu Darvish of Texas
column50: Clay Buchholz of Boston and Adam Wainwright of St. Louis
column51: all of whom had no-hitters in the eighth inning or later but couldn't finish the job and the game.	Darvish came within an out of a perfect game at Houston on April 2. He allowed a hit and didn't finish the game.	Mauer
column52: meanwhile
column53: is making a habit of playing spoiler. It's the third time in his career he's broken up a no-hitter in the ninth inning
column54: according to STATS.	"He's nasty
column55: and he had everything working tonight
column57: you know exactly what is happening
column58: and you don't want to get no-hit. I'm just up there trying to put the bat on the ball. He threw me a really good cutter and I was just able to square it up."	It was Sanchez's second gem in about a month -- he set a franchise record with 17 strikeouts in eight marvelous innings against Atlanta on April 26.	Sanchez (5-4) struck out 12 on Friday and allowed three walks -- staying remarkably calm on the mound all the while.	"He called me out to the mound. In the middle of a no-hitter
column59: Tigers catcher Alex Avila said. I've been in the middle of a no-hitter a few times
column62: I don't think a pitcher's ever called me out to the mound. ... He just forgot what signs we were using when there's a guy on second base."	The home crowd gave Sanchez a standing ovation when he came out to start the ninth
column63: and he immediately struck out Jamey Carroll. Mauer followed with a line drive up the middle -- to almost the same spot where Pittsburgh's Josh Harrison's hit landed last year when he broke up a no-hit bid by Detroit's Justin Verlander
column64: also with two outs to go.	Sanchez instinctively reached up for Mauer's hit
column65: but there was no chance for anyone -- least of all the pitcher -- to catch it. Sanchez then jerked his head back and spun in frustration
column66: but with a bit of a smile on his face.	"We got the hit
column68: Mauer said. He still blew us away."	After Sanchez struck out the next two hitters to end the game
column69: he shared a hug with Avila. Sanchez threw 130 pitches.	"In the end
column70: it's the result of my work. I try to figure out
column71: to put my ball in the strike zone
column72: Sanchez said. It's a nice result
column73: and I take it."	Jordan Zimmermann of Washington
column74: Chris Sale of the Chicago White Sox
column75: Shelby Miller of St. Louis and Jon Lester of Boston have also thrown one-hitters this season. Matt Harvey of the New York Mets allowed one hit in nine innings against the White Sox on May 7
column76: but that game went 10 innings and he didn't finish it.	The last-place Twins have lost 10 straight
column77: and their starting lineup against Sanchez included four players hitting .212 or worse. Carroll drew a walk to lead off the game
column78: and Sanchez issued another to Chris Parmelee in the second. Then the 29-year-old Sanchez
column79: acquired by the Tigers from the Miami Marlins at midseason last year
column80: settled into quite a groove.	He fanned Mauer for the third out of the third
column81: then struck out the side the fourth.	Parmelee led off the fifth with a hard grounder up the middle that Sanchez was able to field himself. The following inning
column82: Brian Dozier nearly broke up the no-hit bid when he hit a slow roller to shortstop Jhonny Peralta and almost beat the throw the first.	Sanchez then struck out Carroll and Mauer to end the Minnesota sixth.	With one out in the eighth
column83: the Twins finally got another runner on base when Eduardo Escobar walked. That snapped a streak of 18 straight hitters retired by Sanchez
column84: but he bounced back to retire pinch-hitter Ryan Doumit on a grounder to first. Pinch-hitter Chris Colabello followed
column85: and with the crowd on its feet
column86: he was called out on strikes.	Miguel Cabrera hit a two-run single in the second
column87: upping his RBI total to 57. Don Kelly added a two-run homer the following inning.	Minnesota's Samuel Deduno (0-1) allowed six runs and nine hits in 5 1/3 innings.	The most recent no-hitter thrown by a Tiger was in 2011
column88: when Verlander tossed the second of his career. The Twins were no-hit last year by Jered Weaver of the Los Angeles Angels.	Game notes	Sanchez's no-hitter as a rookie came Sept. 6
column90: against Arizona. He was pitching for the Marlins then. ... Sanchez threw 121 pitches before being taken out of his 17-strikeout game against the Braves
column91: but there was no way manager Jim Leyland was pulling him Friday while the no-hit bid was in progress.	The Yankees hired former Mets manager Luis Rojas as their new third-base coach on Monday.	Detroit got a jump-start on the winter signings

column1: BOSTON -- John Lackey is rolling again after two rough seasons that made his rich contract seem like a waste of money.	Now the Boston Red Sox are getting what they paid for.	Lackey allowed two hits in seven innings
column2: gave up no earned runs for his second straight start and led the Red Sox to an 8-1 win over the Cleveland Indians on a rainy Friday night.	"I had one bad year and needed surgery afterwards
column3: he said, It's not like I've never been good before."	Lackey was 14-11 in his first season after signing a five-year
column4: $82.5 million contract as a free agent. Then he faltered in 2011
column5: going 12-12 with a 6.41 ERA while battling elbow problems. He had Tommy John surgery after that season and missed all of 2012.	Now he's 3-4 with a 2.72 ERA in a season in which he's allowed more than three earned runs in just one of his seven starts. And he said his elbow feels fine.	"He's not thinking about anything that's taken place in the past
column7: Red Sox manager John Farrell said. The benefit that he had coming into this year was that spring training started 16 months post-op for him
column8: so he was a little bit further along in the recovery than maybe the typical Tommy John" patient.	His season is going so well that the crowd
column9: which booed him often during the 2011 season
column11: Lackey" after he finished his night by striking out Mark Reynolds and Jason Giambi to end the seventh inning.	"It's been a lot of fun
column12: Lackey said. My arm strength is getting better. Endurance is getting better. Things are going on the right track."	Mike Carp began the scoring with a three-run homer in the second
column13: breaking an 0-for-21 slump.	"It definitely means a lot
column14: he said. I've been struggling for playing time and to have a big at bat like that it builds confidence heading into the next couple days."	The homer also ended a 20-inning scoreless streak for Justin Masterson (7-3) and followed a walk to David Ortiz and a single by Mike Napoli.	"This was probably the first (start) I didn't really feel the greatest
column15: Masterson said. I was just kind of pushing (the ball) to the plate. I don't know if the weather had anything to do with that."	The Indians fell out of first place in the AL Central and a half-game behind the Detroit Tigers
column16: who beat the Minnesota Twins 6-0. The Red Sox remained one game behind the AL East-leading New York Yankees
column17: who beat the Tampa Bay Rays 9-4.	It was the second straight strong performance by Lackey. Last Sunday he gave up one hit and one unearned run in six innings of a 5-1 win at Minnesota. He left that game after a three-hour rain delay.	The start of Friday's game was delayed by 44 minutes.	"Both teams play in it
column18: so it's a better night if you're winning
column19: Indians manager Terry Francona said.	Lackey struck out eight, walked three and gave up an unearned run while pitching through a steady rain. He allowed only two of the 25 batters he faced to hit the ball out of the infield.	He had velocity
column20: Francona said. He ended up throwing that cutter very effectively
column21: kind of ran it in on our lefties. As he got more successful with it
column22: he started bringing it off the plate a little bit
column23: opening up the rest of the plate."	He also made a nice fielding play
column24: ranging toward first base to pick up a grounder
column25: skidding on his knees and throwing out speedy Michael Bourn in the sixth.	"It was kind of a crazy night with the rain
column26: kind of got everybody a little off balance probably
column27: catcher Jarrod Saltalamacchia said, but Lack did a great job. I think regardless of anything he was going to go out there and do that."	Former Red Sox manager Francona received an ovation when he walked back to the dugout after making two pitching changes in the seventh
column28: when Boston scored four runs. Francona returned to Fenway Park as an opposing manager on Thursday night for the first time since he was let go by the Red Sox after the 2011 season. The Indians won that game 12-3.	After Carp's homer
column29: the Indians made it 3-1 in the third. Singles by Reynolds and Michael Brantley put runners at first and second before Lackey retired two batters. On a double-steal attempt
column30: Saltalamacchia threw the ball into left field
column31: allowing Reynolds to score and Brantley to reach third.	The Red Sox made it 4-1 in the sixth when they loaded the bases with one out. Daniel Nava was hit by a pitch and Dustin Pedroia and Ortiz singled. Napoli grounded to shortstop Asdrubal Cabrera
column32: who threw to second baseman Jason Kipnis for a forceout. Kipnis' throw to first pulled Nick Swisher off the bag as Napoli reached safely and Nava scored. Pedroia also tried to score
column33: but Swisher threw him out.	Boston took an 8-1 lead in the seventh on two-run singles by Jacoby Ellsbury and Pedroia.	Game notes	Giambi is hitless in his last 26 at bats after going 0-for-4. .. Cleveland activated Swisher off the paternity list and optioned IF Cord Phelps to Triple-A Columbus. ... The Red Sox recalled RHP Alfredo Aceves and IF Jose Iglesias from Triple-A Pawtucket and placed OF Shane Victorino and 3B Will Middlebrooks on the 15-day disabled list. They also activated C David Ross off the 7-day concussion disabled list and sent C Ryan Lavarnway to Pawtucket. ... Cleveland's Scott Kazmir (2-2) faces Jon Lester (6-1) on Saturday in the third game of the four-game series.	Detroit got a jump-start on the winter signings

column1: CINCINNATI --  Ryan Hanigan was surprised he even got the chance.	The Cubs decided to pitch to the Reds catcher with two outs
column2: two on and the pitcher up next.	Hanigan hit a three-run homer that put Cincinnati ahead to stay
column3: and the Reds beat the Cubs 7-4 on Friday night for their fourth straight win.	Joey Votto extended his hitting streak to 12 games with a solo homer
column4: and Brandon Phillips added a two-run shot. But it was Hanigan's second homer that made the difference.	With starter Bronson Arroyo on deck in the fourth inning
column5: Cubs starter Scott Feldman (4-4) fell behind 3-0 in the count to Hanigan
column6: then decided to try to get him out. Hanigan worked the count full before connecting for a 5-3 lead.	Surprised he even got the chance?	"A little bit
column7: Hanigan said. At that point in the game
column8: I didn't think a pinch-hitter was coming in. They went at me and I got a pitch to handle. That was a big turn in the game
column9: a five-run inning."	The game-turning pitch was a hanging curve.	"That was a really bonehead pitch
column10: Feldman said. With the pitcher on deck
column11: I threw the one pitch he can hit for a three-run homer. That one stings a little bit."	The big inning kept the Reds on the upswing. They've won 12 of their past 15 games
column12: surging to a season-high 12 games over .500. At 30-18
column13: they're three wins ahead of their pace last season
column14: when they won 97 games and the NL Central.	They've dominated the Cubs
column15: winning 15 of their past 17. The Reds are 18-5 overall against the Cubs in the past two seasons.	Chicago is last in the NL Central
column16: having lost a season-high five straight. The Cubs (18-29) slid a season-low 11 games under .500.	Votto and Hanigan homered in the fourth inning off Feldman
column17: who had only one bad inning. Feldman gave up five runs in the fourth
column18: the same number he'd allowed in his past five starts combined.	Phillips hit a two-run shot in the eighth off Hector Rondon.	Arroyo (5-4) gave up three runs and six hits in six innings
column19: including Feldman's first career homer. Jonathan Broxton allowed Luis Valbuena's RBI single in the eighth.	Aroldis Chapman pitched the ninth for his 11th save in 13 chances. After blowing a pair of save opportunities
column20: the left-hander has converted his past three. He gave up a single and a walk and fanned three.	The Reds had their third sellout crowd of the season
column21: and the last two games of the series will draw capacity crowds as well.	The Cubs stacked their lineup with six position players and a starting pitcher who bat left-handed
column22: trying a different approach against Arroyo. It worked
column23: but not well enough.	"I didn't feel great the whole game
column25: Arroyo said. They ran seven left-handers against me. They had guys from the left side that I hadn't seen a lot.	"It was a grind for me
column26: to be honest."	Arroyo had trouble keeping his pitches down at the outset. Darwin Barney had a sacrifice fly in the second inning
column27: and Feldman followed with his first career homer
column28: a two-run shot for a 3-0 lead. Cubs pitchers have driven in 15 runs this season
column29: most in the majors.	The three-run inning ended Arroyo's streak of 15 1/3 scoreless innings
column30: his best of the season. The right-hander has won his past three starts.	Feldman had his streak of five impressive starts fall apart in the fourth.	Votto led off with his eighth homer
column31: extending his hitting streak to 12 games
column32: the longest by a Reds player this season. He leads the NL with a .361 batting average.	And that was just the start. Phillips followed with a single
column33: stretching his hitting streak to a season-best 11 games
column34: and eventually scored on Xavier Paul's single. Hanigan's three-run homer -- his second -- made it 5-3.	The five runs matched the most allowed by the Cubs in an inning this season. They were the most earned runs allowed by Feldman in a game this season.	Game notes	 The Reds have homered in each of their past nine games
column35: their longest such streak since 2010. ... The Reds placed LH Sean Marshall on the 15-day DL before the game
column36: the second time he's been sidelined by a sore pitching shoulder this season. LH Manny Parra was activated off the DL to take his place. ... LF Ryan Ludwick said his comeback from shoulder surgery is on schedule. He tore cartilage while sliding into third base on opening day. He's expected back after the All-Star break. ... Umpire Bob Davidson called a balk on Arroyo. ... LH Travis Wood
column37: obtained by Chicago in the trade for Marshall in December 2011
column38: makes his fourth career start against the Reds on Saturday. He's 0-1 with a 4.42 ERA against the Reds.	The Braves added depth at catcher by signing Manny Pina to a two-year
column39: $8 million contract.	Randy Arozarena celebrates with his family at home after learning he won the 2021 AL Rookie of the Year.	From MVP to Cy Young and more

column1: NEW YORK --  An overnight wait was worth it for the Atlanta Braves.	Dan Uggla hit an RBI single in the 10th inning soon after a suspended game resumed
column2: and the Braves beat the New York Mets 7-5 Saturday for their seventh straight win.	"Sometimes you wonder how long these games will last
column3: Atlanta manager Fredi Gonzalez said. I'm glad we were able to finish it off."	Friday night's game was halted because of rain after eight innings with the score 5-all. It took 42 minutes to complete it.	The game picked up right where it left off
column4: at the start of the ninth inning. There was no national anthem
column5: fans were scattered in the stands and it was cloudy and windy with temperatures in the low 50s.	The Mets lost their fourth in a row overall and seventh straight at home. Atlanta and New York were originally scheduled to play Saturday at 7:10 p.m. The resumption ended about 20 minutes before that start time
column6: and the first pitch was pushed back 15 minutes.	"As I said before
column8: you've got to play perfect baseball to win. And so when we don't execute some things
column9: certainly it comes back to hurt us
column10: Mets manager Terry Collins said.	After Justin Upton grounded into inning-ending double play with runners at the corners in the Atlanta ninth, the Braves won it in the 10th.	Freddie Freeman, who homered Friday night before the rain came, drew a leadoff walk from Brandon Lyon (1-2) and took third on a double by Brian McCann.	Uggla, who hit a late home run the previous night at Citi Field, followed with his go-ahead single. B.J. Upton later squeezed home pinch-runner Jordan Schafer.	That was good
column11: heads-up play by them on the bunt. It wasn't called
column12: Gonzalez said.	Anthony Varvaro (2-0) pitched a scoreless ninth. He worked the eighth a day earlier and gave up two runs that made it 5-all. Gonzalez said Varvaro wouldn't pitch in Saturday night's game.	Craig Kimbrel escaped a two-on, no-out jam in the 10th for his 15th save in 18 tries. John Buck was hit by a pitch leading off and Ike Davis, who struck out in all four at-bats Friday, singled for his second hit in 43 at-bats.	But Ruben Tejada popped up a sacrifice bunt try and pinch-hitter Justin Turner grounded into a double play that ended it.	The Braves' previous suspended game was April 5, 1997, against the Cubs -- it was the second game ever played at Turner Field and was stopped because of rain in the seventh inning. Atlanta won the resumption the next day.	The Mets lost in their first suspended game since Aug. 6, 1986, when the second game of a doubleheader against the Cubs was halted after the seventh for darkness -- Wrigley Field didn't have lights then. The Mets won the completion the next day.	When the Mets took the field Saturday, the public-address announcer said Bobby Parnell was now pitching for New York. Greg Burke finished out the eighth Friday night while reliever Robert Carson warmed up.	The Braves took a 5-3 lead in the eighth on a two-run single by pinch-hitter Evan Gattis. The Mets evened it in the bottom half against Varvaro, who struggled to get a good grip but threw a wild pitch that let the tying run score.	The game was suspended after a 75-minute delay. The start was delayed by rain for 16 minutes.	Uggla hit a solo homer in the Atlanta seventh that made it 3-all. Buck had also connected.	Game notes	 Gonzalez said RHP Brandon Beachy (Tommy John surgery in 2012) is progressing well." Beachy pitched four innings and gave up two runs Friday night in a Triple-A rehab start. ... Atlanta RHP Jordan Walden (shoulder inflammation) threw a side session Friday and will have another one Sunday. ... The clubs combined TV crews to show the resumption
column13: with Mets announcer Keith Hernandez working with Braves broadcaster Joe Simpson. The regularly scheduled game was a Fox national game.	The Braves added depth at catcher by signing Manny Pina to a two-year
column14: $8 million contract.	Randy Arozarena celebrates with his family at home after learning he won the 2021 AL Rookie of the Year.	From MVP to Cy Young and more

column2: Fla. -- Another injury marred a New York Yankees' victory.	Outfielder Curtis Granderson broke the knuckle on his left pinkie finger in the Yankees' 9-4 win over the Tampa Bay Rays on Friday night.	Yankees manager Joe Girardi had no official timeline for how long Granderson will be out
column3: but indicated it could be a minimum of four weeks.	"It is what it is
column4: said Granderson, who will see a hand specialist in New York on Monday. You can't change it right now
column5: you've got to move forward."	Granderson broke the knuckle getting hit by Cesar Ramos' pitch in the fifth. After later scoring
column6: he was replaced defensively by Ichiro Suzuki in the bottom of the inning.	Granderson missed the first 38 games this season with a broken right forearm
column7: the result of a hit by pitch in his first at-bat at spring training.	"Another bump in the road
column8: Granderson said.	Granderson said at this point he was told surgery will not be required.	It's sad
column9: Yankees second baseman Robinson Cano said. It's really tough. He's one of those guys you're going to miss. Hopefully he gets back soon."	David Phelps (3-2)
column10: who retired his first 13 batters before James Loney hit a one-out double in the fifth
column11: allowed four runs and six hits in 7 2/3 innings. He left in the eighth after he was hit on the right forearm by a drive up the middle by Ben Zobrist.	X-rays were negative
column12: and Phelps did not rule out making his next start.	"It's a little sore
column13: Phelps said. See how that feels tomorrow morning will be a bigger thing. I'll be fine."	The Yankees have been hit hard by injuries this season. Derek Jeter
column16: Mark Teixeira and Kevin Youkilis are among the players on the disabled list.	"I'm happy that we won the game
column17: but you lost a really good player
column18: Girardi said. That's never a good thing."	Brett Gardner
column19: Lyle Overbay and Jayson Nix each drove in two runs for the Yankees.	Gardner made it 5-0 with a two-run homer off Roberto Hernandez (2-5) during the fourth. The Yankees took a 3-0 lead in the second on Overbay's two-run double and an RBI single by Nix.	Tampa Bay slugger Evan Longoria went 0 for 4 and had his career-best 16-game hitting streak end.	Nix walked with the bases loaded
column20: Chris Stewart had a run-scoring single and Cano picked up an RBI when he was hit by Ramos' pitch as the Yankees went ahead 8-0 in the fifth.	Matt Joyce had an RBI double during the Rays' three-run sixth.	Nix tripled and scored to put the Yankees up 9-3 on a wild pitch in the seventh.	After falling behind 3-0 in the third
column21: the Rays intentionally walked Cano with runners on first and second and two outs. The move proved successful when Hernandez got an infield pop fly from Vernon Wells.	Hernandez gave up five runs
column22: six hits and three walks in four innings. He was coming off a start last Saturday against Baltimore where he allowed five runs and eight hits over two innings.	"Pitching won the game for them and not for us
column23: Rays manager Joe Maddon said. I thought we had some good at-bats
column24: but they did beat us on the mound. We have to pitch better to win."	Tampa Bay's Matt Moore will look Saturday to become the fifth-youngest pitcher since 1916 to start a season 9-0 exclusively as a starter. The 23-year old left-hander will go against Vidal Nuno (1-1).	According to the Rays
column25: if Moore gets the win Saturday
column26: only Ken Holtzman (1967)
column27: Livan Hernandez (1997)
column28: Roger Clemens (1986) and Jered Weaver (2006) will have accomplished the feat at a younger age.	Game notes	Maddon said AL Cy Young Award winner David Price
column29: who went on the 15-day disabled list May 16 with a left triceps strain
column30: is getting well. "I don't have any kind of finish line there yet
column31:
Maddon said. ... The Yankees are 11-5 since May 8.	In a free-agent field filled with future Hall of Famers, Detroit added one of the most undervalued pitchers available this winter.	Joon Lee breaks down how Eduardo Rodriguez signing with Detroit affects the Tigers and Red Sox.	Check out some of the most electric moments from Vladimir Guerrero Jr.'s career.	Former Boston Red Sox left-hander Eduardo Rodriguez and the Detroit Tigers are in agreement on a five-year deal worth $77 million, sources confirmed to ESPN.	From who we think deserves MVP and Cy Young to if the voters got it right, this is your one-stop shop as baseball's 2021 hardware is handed out.	Even Shohei Ohtani, arguably the best player in the major leagues, feels down at times, particularly when his team isn't winning.
